{{About|the Orphan Train Movement|the TV movie|Orphan Train (film)}} [[File:Orphan Train.jpg|thumb|Orphan train]] The '''Orphan Train Movement''' was a supervised welfare program that transported orphaned and homeless children from crowded Eastern cities of the United States to foster homes located largely in rural areas of the [[Midwestern United States|Midwest]]. The orphan trains operated between 1854 and 1929, relocating about 200,000 orphaned, abandoned, abused, or homeless children.
Three charitable institutions, [[Children's Village]] (founded 1851 by 24 philanthropists),<ref name=NYT-1860>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1860/01/31/news/our-city-charities-no-ii-the-new-york-juvenile-asylum.html?pagewanted=all|title=OUR CITY CHARITIES--NO. II.; The New-York Juvenile Asylum.|work=[[New York Times]]|date=January 31, 1860|accessdate=November 21, 2015}} *<sup>a</sup> "...from the most careful inquiry, they regard suited to have the charge of such children. '''Six years of experience''' have increased their caution and watchfulness in this matter, and they now require such guarantees on the part of the masters as will, in their judgment, most conduce to the good of their wards. Regular reports are required both from the children and their masters, and the agent of the asylum visits the greater part of the children when making his trips to locate new companies. In this way, very few are lost sight of, and the results thus far, in the case of those indentured within two years past, are very gratifying." — ¶ 13 *<sup>b</sup> "On the 30th of June, 1851, the act of incorporation was passed. The corporators named in the act were [[Robert Bowne Minturn|Robert B. Minturn]], [[Myndert Van Schaick]], Robert M. Stratton, Solomon Jenner, Albert Gilbert, Stewart Brown, [[Francis R. Tillou]], David S. Kennedy, Joseph B. Collins, [[Benjamin Franklin Butler (lawyer)|Benjamin F. Butler]], [[Isaac Hopper|Isaac T. Hopper]], Charles Partridge, [[Luther Bradish]], Christopher Y. Wemple, [[Charles O'Conor (American politician)|Charles O'Conor]], [[John Dennison Russ|John D. Russ]], [[John Duer]], [[Peter Cooper]], Apollos R. Wetmore, Frederick S. Winston, James Kelly, Silas C. Herring, Rensselaer N. Havens, and [[John W. Edmonds]]" — ¶ 7</ref> the [[Children's Aid Society]] (established 1853 by [[Charles Loring Brace]]) and later, the [[The New York Foundling|New York Foundling Hospital]], endeavored to help these children. The institutions were supported by wealthy donors and operated by professional staff. The three institutions developed a program that placed homeless, orphaned, and abandoned city children, who numbered an estimated 30,000 in New York City alone in the 1850s, in foster homes throughout the country. The children were transported to their new homes on [[train]]s that were labeled "orphan trains" or "baby trains". This relocation of children ended in the 1920s with the beginning of organized [[foster care]] in America.
==Background== [[File:CharlesLoringBrace.jpg|thumb|left|Charles Loring Brace]]
The first [[orphanage]] in the United States was reportedly established in 1729 in [[Natchez, Mississippi|Natchez, MS]],<ref name="Warren">[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/national/horizon/nov98/orphan.htm Warren, Andrea. "The Orphan Train", ''The Washington Post'', 1998]</ref> but institutional orphanages were uncommon before the early 19th century. Relatives or neighbors usually raised children who had lost parents. Arrangements were informal and rarely involved courts.<ref name="Warren" />
Around 1830, the number of homeless children in large Eastern cities such as New York City exploded. In 1850, there were an estimated 10,000 to 30,000 homeless children in New York City. At the time, New York City's population was only 500,000.<ref name="Warren" /> Some children were orphaned when their parents died in epidemics of typhoid, yellow fever or the flu.<ref name="Warren" /> Others were abandoned due to poverty, illness or addiction.<ref name="Warren" /> Many children sold matches, rags, or newspapers to survive.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/amex/orphan/|title=American Experience . The Orphan Trains {{!}} PBS|website=www.pbs.org|access-date=2016-11-28}}</ref> For protection against street violence, they banded together and formed gangs.<ref name=":0" />
In 1853, a young minister named [[Charles Loring Brace]] became concerned with the plight of street children (often known as "street Arabs").<ref name=":0" /> He founded the Children's Aid Society.<ref name=":0" /> During its first year the Children's Aid Society primarily offered boys religious guidance and vocational and academic instruction. Eventually, the society established the nation's first runaway shelter, the Newsboys' Lodging House, where vagrant boys received inexpensive room and board and basic education. Brace and his colleagues attempted to find jobs and homes for individual children, but they soon became overwhelmed by the numbers needing placement. Brace hit on the idea of sending groups of children to rural areas for adoption.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/books/first/o/oconnor-01orphan.html|title=Orphan Trains|website=www.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-11-28}}</ref>
Brace believed that street children would have better lives if they left the poverty and debauchery of their lives in New York City and were instead raised by morally upright farm families.<ref name="cas">[http://www.childrensaidsociety.org/about/history "History", Children's Aid Society]</ref> Recognizing the need for labor in the expanding farm country, Brace believed that farmers would welcome homeless children, take them into their homes and treat them as their own. His program would turn out to be a forerunner of modern foster care.<ref name=":0" />
After a year of dispatching children individually to farms in nearby Connecticut, Pennsylvania and rural New York, the Children's Aid Society mounted its first large-scale expedition to the Midwest in September 1854.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1986-09-28/features/8602270532_1_charles-loring-brace-orphan-trains-noah-lawyer|title=Trains Ferried Waifs To New Lives On The Prairie|newspaper=tribunedigital-sunsentinel|access-date=2016-11-28}}</ref>
== The term "Orphan Train" == The phrase "orphan train" was first used in 1854 to describe the transportation of children from their home area via the railroad.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=S.|first=Trammell, Rebecca|date=2009-01-01|title=Orphan Train Myths and Legal Reality|url=http://digitalcommons.wcl.american.edu/tma/vol5/iss2/3/|journal=The Modern American|volume=5|issue=2}}</ref> However, the term "Orphan Train" was not widely used until long after the Orphan Train program had ended.<ref name=":1" />
The Children's Aid Society referred to its relevant division first as the Emigration Department, then as the Home-Finding Department, and finally, as the Department of Foster Care.<ref name=":1" /> Later, the New York Foundling Hospital sent out what it called "baby" or "mercy" trains.<ref name=":1" />
Organizations and families generally used the terms "family placement" or "out-placement" ("out" to distinguish it from the placement of children "in" orphanages or asylums) to refer to orphan train passengers.<ref name=":1" />
Widespread use of the term "orphan train" may date to 1978, when [[CBS]] aired a fictional miniseries entitled The Orphan Trains. One reason the term was not used by placement agencies was that less than half of the children who rode the trains were in fact orphans, and as many as 25 percent had two living parents. Children with both parents living ended up on the trains — or in orphanages — because their families did not have the money or desire to raise them or because they had been abused or abandoned or had run away. And many teenage boys and girls went to orphan train sponsoring organizations simply in search of work or a free ticket out of the city.<ref name=":1" />
The term "orphan trains" is also misleading because a substantial number of the placed-out children didn't take the railroad to their new homes and some didn't even travel very far. The state that received the greatest number of children (nearly one-third of the total) was New York. Connecticut, New Jersey, and Pennsylvania also received substantial numbers of children. For most of the orphan train era, the Children's Aid Society bureaucracy made no distinction between local placements and even its most distant ones. They were all written up in the same record books and, on the whole, managed by the same people. Also, the same child might be placed one time in the West and the next time — if the first home did not work out — in New York City. The decision about where to place a child was made almost entirely on the basis of which alternative was most readily available at the moment the child needed help.<ref name=":1" />
== The first Orphan Train == The first group of 45 children arrived in [[Dowagiac, Michigan]], on October 1, 1854.<ref name=":1" /> The children had traveled for days in uncomfortable conditions. They were accompanied by E. P. Smith of the Children's Aid Society.<ref name=":1" /> Smith himself had let two different passengers on the riverboat from Manhattan adopt boys without checking their references.<ref name=":4">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=FMUlOcn61q4C&pg=PA148&lpg=PA148&dq=boston+orphan+train+little+wanderers#v=onepage&q=boston%20orphan%20train%20little%20wanderers&f=false|title=Orphan Trains: The Story of Charles Loring Brace and the Children He Saved and Failed|last=O'Connor|first=Stephen|date=2004-03-01|publisher=University of Chicago Press|isbn=9780226616674|language=en}}</ref> Smith added a boy he met in the Albany railroad yard — a boy whose claim to orphanhood Smith never bothered to verify.<ref name=":1" /> At a meeting in Dowagiac, Smith played on his audience's sympathy while pointing out that the boys were handy and the girls could be used for all types of housework.<ref name=":1" />
In an account of the trip published by the Children's Aid Society, Smith said that in order to get a child, applicants had to have recommendations from their pastor and a justice of the peace, but it is unlikely that this requirement was strictly enforced.<ref name=":1" /> By the end of that first day, fifteen boys and girls had been placed with local families. Five days later, twenty-two more children had been adopted. Smith and the remaining eight children traveled to Chicago where Smith put them on a train to Iowa City by themselves where a Reverend C. C. Townsend, who ran a local orphanage, took them in and attempted to find them foster families.<ref name=":1" /> This first expedition was considered such a success that in January 1855 the society sent out two more parties of homeless children to Pennsylvania.<ref name=":1" />
==Logistics of Orphan Trains== [[File:Orphan train flyer.jpg|thumb|Orphan train flyer]]
Committees of prominent local citizens were organized in the towns where orphan trains stopped. These committees were responsible for arranging a site for the adoptions, publicizing the event, and arranging lodging for the orphan train group. These committees were also required to consult with the Children's Aid Society on the suitability of local families interested in adopting children.<ref name=":4" />
Brace's system put its faith in the kindness of strangers.<ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/amex/orphan/orphants.html|title=American Experience . The Orphan Trains {{!}} PBS|website=www.pbs.org|access-date=2016-11-28}}</ref> Orphan train children were placed in homes for free and were expected to serve as an extra pair of hands to help with chores around the farm.<ref name="cas" /> Families expected to raise them as they would their natural-born children, providing them with decent food and clothing, a "common" education, and $100 when they turned twenty-one.<ref name=":1" /> Older children placed by The Children's Aid Society were supposed to be paid for their labors.<ref name="cas" /> Legal adoption was not required.<ref name=":5" />
According to the Children's Aid Society's "Terms on Which Boys are Placed in Homes," boys under twelve were to be "treated by the applicants as one of their own children in matters of schooling, clothing, and training," and boys twelve to fifteen were to be "sent to a school a part of each year."<ref name="dan">[http://www.neh.gov/humanities/2007/novemberdecember/feature/lost-children-riders-the-orphan-train Scheuerman, Dan. "Lost Children: Riders on the Orphan Train", ''Humanities'', November/December 2007 | Volume 28, Number 6]</ref> Representatives from the society were supposed to visit each family once a year to check conditions, and children were expected to write letters back to the society twice a year.<ref name="dan" /> There were only a handful of agents to monitor thousands of placements.<ref name=":5" />
Before they boarded the train, children were dressed in new clothing, given a Bible and placed in the care of Children's Aid Society agents who accompanied them west.<ref name="Warren" /> Few children understood what was happening. Once they did, their reactions ranged from delight at finding a new family to anger and resentment at being <nowiki>''placed out'' when they had relatives ''back home.''</nowiki><ref name="Warren" />
Most children on the trains were white. An attempt was made to place non-English speakers with people who spoke their language.<ref name="Warren" /> German-speaking [[Bill Landkamer]] rode an orphan train several times as a preschooler in the 1920s before being accepted by a German family in Nebraska.<ref name="Warren" />
Babies were easiest to place, but finding homes for children older than 14 was always difficult because of concern that they were too set in their ways or might have bad habits.<ref name="Warren" /> Children who were physically or mentally disabled or sickly were difficult to find homes for.<ref name="Warren" /> Although many siblings were sent out together on orphan trains, prospective parents could choose to take a single child, separating siblings.<ref name=":6">{{Cite news|url=http://www.mcphersonsentinel.com/news/20161116/orphan-trains-focus-of-upcoming-program|title=Orphan trains focus of upcoming program|last=Writer|first=Patricia Middleton Staff|newspaper=McPhersonSentinel|access-date=2016-11-28}}</ref>
Many orphan train children went to live with families that placed orders specifying age, gender, and hair and eye color.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.twincities.com/2015/09/30/they-survived-minnesotas-orphan-trains-to-celebrate-life/|title=They survived Minnesota's orphan trains to celebrate life – Twin Cities|access-date=2016-11-28}}</ref> Others were paraded from the depot into a local playhouse, where they were put up on stage, thus the origin of the term "up for adoption."<ref name="dan" /> According to an exhibit panel from the National Orphan Train Complex, the children "took turns giving their names, singing a little ditty, or 'saying a piece."<ref name="dan" /> According to Sara Jane Richter, professor of history at Oklahoma Panhandle State University, the children often had unpleasant experiences. "People came along and prodded them, and looked, and felt, and saw how many teeth they had."<ref name="dan" />
Press accounts convey the spectacle, and sometimes auction-like atmosphere, attending the arrival of a new group of children. <nowiki>''</nowiki>Some ordered boys, others girls, some preferred light babies, others dark, and the orders were filled out properly and every new parent was delighted,<nowiki>''</nowiki> reported ''The Daily Independent'' of [[Grand Island, Nebraska|Grand Island, NE]] in May 1912. <nowiki>''</nowiki>They were very healthy tots and as pretty as anyone ever laid eyes on.<nowiki>''</nowiki><ref name="Warren" />
Brace raised money for the program through his writings and speeches. Wealthy people occasionally sponsored trainloads of children.<ref name="Warren" /> Charlotte Augusta Gibbs, wife of [[John Jacob Astor III]], had sent 1,113 children west on the trains by 1884.<ref name=":3" /> Railroads gave discount fares to the children and the agents who cared for them.<ref name="Warren" />
== Scope of the Orphan Train movement == The Children's Aid Society's sent an average of 3,000 children via train each year from 1855 to 1875.<ref name="Warren" /> Orphan trains were sent to 45 states, as well as Canada and Mexico. During the early years, Indiana received the largest number of children.<ref name="cas" /> At the beginning of the Children's Aid Society orphan train program, children were not sent to the southern states, as Brace was an ardent abolitionist.<ref name=":6" />
By the 1870s, the New York Foundling Hospital and the New England Home for Little Wanderers in Boston all had orphan train programs of their own.<ref name=":4" />
== New York Foundling Hospital "Mercy Trains" == {{Main|New York Foundling}} The [[New York Foundling]] Hospital was established in 1869 by [[Sister Irene|Sister Mary Irene Fitzgibbon]] of the [[Sisters of Charity of New York]] as a shelter for abandoned infants. The Sisters worked in conjunction with Priests throughout the Midwest and South in an effort to place these children in Catholic families. The Foundling Hospital sent infants and toddlers to prearranged Roman Catholic homes from 1875 to 1914.<ref name="Warren" /> Parishioners in the destination regions were asked to accept children, and parish priests provided applications to approved families. This practice was first known as the "Baby Train," then later the "Mercy Train." By the 1910s, 1,000 children a year were placed with new families.<ref>Dianne Creagh, "The Baby Trains: Catholic Foster Care and Western Migration, 1873-1929," ''Journal of Social History'' (2012) 46#1 pp 197-218 [http://muse.jhu.edu/journals/journal_of_social_history/v046/46.1.creagh.html online]</ref>
== Challenges faced by Orphan Train passengers and families == Linda McCaffery, a professor at Barton County Community College, explained the range of Orphan Train experiences: "Many were used as strictly slave farm labor, but there are stories, wonderful stories of children ending up in fine families that loved them, cherished them, [and] educated them."<ref name="dan" />
Orphan train children faced obstacles ranging from prejudice of classmates because they were <nowiki>''train children''</nowiki> to feeling like outsiders in their families all their lives.<ref name="Warren" /> Many rural people viewed the orphan train children with suspicion, as incorrigible offspring of drunkards and prostitutes.<ref name=":5" />
Criticisms of the orphan train movement focused on concerns that initial placements were made hastily, without proper investigation, and that there was insufficient follow-up on placements. Charities were also criticized for not keeping track of children placed while under their care.<ref name=":3" /> In 1883, Brace consented to an independent investigation. It found the local committees were ineffective at screening foster parents. Supervision was lax. Many older boys had run away. But its overall conclusion was positive. The majority of children under fourteen were leading satisfactory lives.<ref name=":5" />
Applicants for children were supposed to be screened by committees of local businessmen, ministers, or physicians, but the screening was rarely very thorough.<ref name=":1" /> Small-town ministers, judges, and other local leaders were often reluctant to reject a potential foster parent as unfit if he were also a friend or customer.<ref name=":2" />
Many children lost their identity through forced name changes and repeated moves.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.americanbar.org/groups/child_law/orphan-train.html|title=Orphan Train|website=www.americanbar.org|access-date=2016-11-28}}</ref> In 1996, Alice Ayler said, "I was one of the luckier ones because I know my heritage. They took away the identity of the younger riders by not allowing contact with the past."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://newsok.com/article/2542773|title=Students Learn About Orphan Train|date=1996-06-12|newspaper=NewsOK.com|language=en-US|access-date=2016-11-28}}</ref>
Many children placed out west had survived on the streets of New York, Boston or other large eastern cities and generally they were not the obedient children many families expected.<ref name=":3" /> In 1880, a Mr. Coffin of Indiana editorialized, "Children so thrown out from the cities are a source of much corruption in the country places where they are thrown... Very few such children are useful."<ref name=":7">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=5Po3FdgqOw4C&pg=PA29&dq=orphan+train+slavery#v=onepage&q=orphan%20train%20&f=false|title=Little Strangers: Portrayals of Adoption and Foster Care in America, 1850-1929|last=Nelson|first=Claudia|date=2003-05-13|publisher=Indiana University Press|isbn=0253109809|language=en}}</ref>
Some placement locations charged that orphan trains were dumping undesirable children from the East on Western communities.<ref name=":3" /> In 1874, the National Prison Reform Congress charged that these practices resulted in increased correctional expenses in the West.<ref name=":3" />
Older boys wanted to be paid for their labor, sometimes asking for additional pay or leaving a placement to find a higher paying placement. It is estimated that young men initiated 80% of the placement changes.<ref name=":3" />
One of the many children who rode the train was Lee Nailling. Lee's mother died of sickness; after her death Lee's father could not afford to keep his children. {{Citation needed|date=February 2017}} Another orphan train child was named Alice Ayler. Alice rode the train because her single mother could not provide for her children; before the journey they lived off of "berries" and "green water."{{Citation needed|date=February 2017}}
Catholic clergy maintained that some charities were deliberately placing Catholic children in Protestant homes to change their religious practices.<ref name=":3" /> The Society for the Protection of Destitute Roman Catholic Children in the City of New York (known as the Protectory) was founded in 1863. The Protectory ran orphanages and place out programs for Catholic youth in response to Brace's Protestant-centered program.<ref name=":7" /> Similar charges of conversion via adoption were made concerning the placement of Jewish children.<ref name=":3" />
Not all orphan train children were true orphans, but were made into orphans by forced removal from their biological families to be placed out in other states.<ref name=":3" /> Some claimed this was a deliberate pattern intended to break up immigrant Catholic families.<ref name=":3" /> Some abolitionists opposed placements of children with Western families, viewing indentureship as a form of slavery.<ref name=":3" />
Orphan trains were the target of lawsuits, generally filed by parents seeking to reclaim their children.<ref name=":3" /> Suits were occasionally filed by a receiving parent or family member claiming to have lost money or been harmed as the result of the placement.<ref name=":3" />
The Minnesota State Board of Corrections and Charities reviewed Minnesota orphan train placements between 1880 and 1883. The Board found that while children were placed hastily and without proper investigation into their placements, only a few children were "depraved" or abused. The review criticized local committee members who were swayed by pressure from wealthy and important individuals in their community. The Board also pointed out that older children were frequently placed with farmers who expected to profit from their labor. The Board recommended that paid agents replace or supplement local committees in investigating and reviewing all applications and placements.<ref name=":3" />
A complicated lawsuit arose from a 1904 Arizona Territory orphan train placement in which the New York Foundling Hospital sent 40 Caucasian children between the ages of 18 months and 5 years to be indentured to Catholic families in an Arizona Territory parish. The families approved by the local priest for placement were identified in the subsequent litigation as "Mexican Indian." Nuns escorting these children were unaware of the racial tension between local Anglo and Mexican groups, and placed Caucasian children with Mexican Indian families. A group of white men, described as "just short of a lynch mob," forcibly took the children from the Mexican Indian homes and placed most of them with Anglo families. Some of the children were returned to the Foundling Hospital, but 19 remained with the Anglo Arizona Territory families. The Foundling Hospital filed a writ of habeas corpus seeking the return of these children. The Arizona Supreme Court held that the best interests of the children required that they remain in their new Arizona homes. On appeal, the [[Supreme Court of the United States|U.S. Supreme Court]] found that a writ of habeas corpus seeking the return of a child constituted an improper use of the writ. Habeas corpus writs should be used "solely in cases of arrest and forcible imprisonment under color or claim of warrant of law," and should not be used to obtain or transfer custody of children. These events were well publicized at the time with newspaper stories titled "Babies Sold Like Sheep," telling readers that the New York Foundling Hospital "has for years been shipping children in car-loads all over the country, and they are given away and sold like cattle."<ref name=":3" />
== End of the Orphan Train movement == As the West was settled, the demand for adoptable children declined.<ref name=":3" /> Additionally, Midwestern cities such as Chicago, Cleveland and St. Louis began to experience the neglected children problems that New York, Boston and Philadelphia had experienced in the mid-1800s. These cities began to seek ways to care for their own orphan populations.<ref name=":3" />
In 1895, Michigan passed a statute prohibiting out-of-state children from local placement without payment of a bond guaranteeing that children placed in Michigan would not become a public charge in the State.<ref name=":3" /> Similar laws were passed by Indiana, Illinois, Kansas, Minnesota, Missouri and Nebraska.<ref name=":3" /> Negotiated agreements between one or more New York charities and several western states allowed the continued placement of children in these states. Such agreements included large bonds as security for placed children. In 1929, however, these agreements expired and were not renewed as charities changed their child care support strategies.<ref name=":3" />
Lastly, the need for the orphan train movement decreased as legislation was passed providing in-home family support. Charities began developing programs to support destitute and needy families limiting the need for intervention to place out children.<ref name=":3" />
== Legacy of the program == Between 1854 and 1929, an estimated 200,000 American children traveled west by rail in search of new homes.<ref name="Warren" />
The Children's Aid Society rated its transplanted wards successful if they grew into "creditable members of society," and frequent reports documented the success stories. A 1910 survey concluded that 87 percent of the children sent to country homes had "done well," while 8 percent had returned to New York and the other 5 percent had either died, disappeared or gotten arrested.<ref name=":2" />
Brace's notion that children are better cared for by families than in institutions is the most basic tenet of present-day foster care.<ref name=":1" />
== Organizations == [[File:OrphanTrainMuseumOpening.jpg|thumb|right|[[Union Pacific Railroad Depot (Concordia, Kansas)|National Orphan Train Complex]] dedication]]The Orphan Train Heritage Society of America, Inc. founded in 1986 in [[Springdale, AR]] preserves the history of the orphan train era.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.encyclopediaofarkansas.net/encyclopedia/entry-detail.aspx?entryID=2400|title=Orphan Train Heritage Society of America, Inc. (OTHSA) - Encyclopedia of Arkansas|website=www.encyclopediaofarkansas.net|access-date=2016-11-28}}</ref> The National Orphan Train Complex in [[Concordia, KS]] is a museum and research center dedicated to the Orphan Train Movement, the various institutions that participated, and the children and agents who rode the trains.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.kansassampler.org/8wonders/historyresults.php?id=288|title=The 8 Wonders of Kansas History - A Kansas Sampler Foundation Project|last=inc.|first=designed by: logicmaze|website=www.kansassampler.org|access-date=2016-11-28}}</ref> The museum is located at the restored [[Union Pacific Railroad Depot (Concordia, Kansas)|Union Pacific Railroad Depot]] in Concordia which is listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]]. The Complex maintains an archive of riders' stories and houses a research facility. Services offered by the museum include rider research, educational material, and a collection of photos and other memorabilia.

==Pre-war== The first mass deportation of Jews from Nazi Germany occurred in less than a year before the outbreak of war. It was the forcible eviction of German Jews with Polish citizenship fuelled by the ''[[Kristallnacht]]''. Approximately 30,000 Jews were rounded up and sent via rail to refugee camps. In July 1938, both the United States and Britain at the [[Évian Conference]] in France refused to accept any more Jewish immigrants.<ref name="YV1938">{{Citation|author=Yad Vashem |title=Nazi Germany and the Jews 1933-1939 |year=2014 |url=http://www.yadvashem.org/yv/en/holocaust/about/01/crucial_year.asp |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140207012203/http://www.yadvashem.org/yv/en/holocaust/about/01/crucial_year.asp |archivedate=2014-02-07 |url-status=dead }}</ref> The [[British Government]] agreed to take in the shipment of children arranged by the [[Kindertransport]] scheme, some 10,000 eventually arriving in the UK. All European Jews trapped under the Nazi regime became the target of Hitler's "Final Solution to the Jewish Question".<ref name="Bülow">{{Citation|author=Louis Bülow |title=Sir Nicholas Winton |year=2014 |url=http://www.auschwitz.dk/Winton.htm |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140207015207/http://www.auschwitz.dk/Winton.htm |archivedate=2014-02-07 |url-status=dead }}</ref>
==The role of railways in the Final Solution== [[File:Birkenau gate.JPG|thumb|250px|left|Entrance, or so-called "death gate", to Auschwitz II-Birkenau, the extermination camp]] Within various phases of [[the Holocaust]], the trains were employed differently. At first, they were used to [[Jewish ghettos in German-occupied Poland|concentrate the Jewish populations in the ghettos]], and often to transport them to [[Forced labour under German rule during World War II|forced labour]] and [[German camps in occupied Poland during World War II|German concentration camps]] for the purpose of economic exploitation.<ref name="ushmm-7445">[http://www.ushmm.org/wlc/sp/article.php?ModuleId=10007445 Types of Ghettos. United States Holocaust Memorial Museum, Washington, D.C.]</ref><ref name="Hilberg"/> In 1939, for logistical reasons, the Jewish communities in settlements without railway lines in [[occupied Poland]] were dissolved.<ref name="holocaustchronicle">[http://www.holocaustchronicle.org/staticpages/176.html "1939: The War Against The Jews."] ''The Holocaust Chronicle'' published by Publications International, April 2000.</ref> By the end of 1941, about 3.5 million [[Polish Jews]] had been segregated and ghettoised by the ''[[SS]]'' in a massive deportation action involving the use of freight trains.<ref name="Berenbaum">[[Michael Berenbaum]], ''The World Must Know'', [[United States Holocaust Memorial Museum]], 2006, p. 114.</ref> Permanent ghettos had direct railway connections, because the food aid (paid for by the Jews themselves) was completely dependent on the ''SS'', similar to all newly built labour camps.<ref name="holocaust-education.dk">Peter Vogelsang & Brian B. M. Larsen, [http://www.holocaust-education.dk/holocaust/ghettoer.asp "The Ghettos of Poland."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131022181155/http://www.holocaust-education.dk/holocaust/ghettoer.asp |date=2013-10-22 }} ''The Danish Center for Holocaust and Genocide Studies''. 2002.</ref> Jews were legally banned from baking bread.<ref name="Edelman-upenn">{{cite web |url=http://www.writing.upenn.edu/~afilreis/Holocaust/warsaw-uprising.html |title=The Ghetto Fights |publisher=Literature of the Holocaust, at the University of Pennsylvania |work=The Warsaw Ghetto: The 45th Anniversary of the Uprising |author=Marek Edelman}}</ref> They were sealed off from the general public in hundreds of virtual prison-islands called ''Jüdische Wohnbezirke'' or ''Wohngebiete der Juden''. However, the new system was unsustainable. By the end of 1941, most ghettoised Jews had no savings left to pay the ''SS'' for further bulk food deliveries.<ref name="holocaust-education.dk"/> The quagmire was resolved at the [[Wannsee conference]] of 20 January 1942 near [[Berlin]], where the "Final Solution of the Jewish question" (''die Endlösung der Judenfrage'') was set in place.<ref name="Furet">[[François Furet]], ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=02PpAAAACAAJ Unanswered Questions: Nazi Germany and the Genocide of the Jews]''. Schocken Books (1989), p. 182; {{ISBN|0-8052-4051-9}}.</ref> It was a [[euphemism]] referring to the Nazi plan for the annihilation of the Jewish people.<ref name=Museum>{{cite web |title='Final Solution': Overview |url=http://www.ushmm.org/wlc/en/article.php?ModuleId=10005151 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130302130042/http://www.ushmm.org/wlc/en/article.php?ModuleId=10005151 |archive-date=2 March 2013 |publisher= United States Holocaust Memorial Museum |author=Holocaust Encyclopedia}}</ref>
During the liquidation of the ghettos starting in 1942, the trains were used to transport the condemned populations to death camps. To implement the "Final Solution", the Nazis made their own ''Deutsche Reichsbahn'' an indispensable element of the mass extermination machine, wrote historian [[Raul Hilberg]].<ref name="Hilberg">{{cite journal |title=German Railroads / Jewish Souls |journal=The Role of the German Railroads in the Destruction of the Jews |volume = 35|issue=2 |pages=162–174 |author=Raul Hilberg|doi=10.1007/BF02838139 |year = 1998}}</ref> Although the prisoner trains took away valuable track space, they allowed for the mass scale and shortened duration over which the extermination needed to take place. The fully enclosed nature of the locked and windowless cattle wagons greatly reduced the number and skill of troops required to transport the condemned Jews to their destinations. The use of railroads enabled the Nazis to lie about the "resettlement program" and, at the same time, build and operate more efficient gassing facilities which required limited supervision.<ref name="explained.org">{{cite web |url=http://www.theholocaustexplained.org/ks3/the-camps/daily-life/journeys/ |title=Deportation and transportation |publisher=London Jewish Cultural Centre |work=The Holocaust Explained |year=2011 |accessdate=6 February 2014}}</ref>
The Nazis disguised their "Final Solution" as the mass "resettlement to the east". The victims were told they were being taken to labour camps in [[Reichskommissariat Ukraine|Ukraine]]. In reality, from 1942 on, for most Jews, deportations meant only death at either [[Bełżec extermination camp|Bełżec]], [[Chełmno extermination camp|Chełmno]], [[Sobibor extermination camp|Sobibór]], [[Majdanek concentration camp|Majdanek]], [[Treblinka extermination camp|Treblinka]], or [[Auschwitz-Birkenau]]. Some trains that had already transported goods to the Eastern front on their return carried human cargo bound for extermination camps.<ref name="chronicle.org">{{cite web |url=http://www.holocaustchronicle.org/staticpages/415.html |title=Reichsbahn |publisher=Publications International |work=Death and Resistance |accessdate=6 February 2014 |author=The Holocaust Chronicle |page=415}}</ref> The plan was being realized in the utmost secrecy. In late 1942, during a telephone conversation, Hitler's private secretary [[Martin Bormann]] admonished [[Heinrich Himmler]], who was informing him about 50,000 Jews already exterminated in a concentration camp in Poland. "They were not exterminated – Bormann screamed – only evacuated, evacuated, evacuated!", and slammed down the phone, wrote Enghelberg.<ref name="Enghelberg">{{cite book |url=https://www.amazon.com/HOLOCAUST-transport-companies-agreement-operation-ebook/dp/B004C44N58/ref=sr_1_10?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1391784099&sr=1-10#reader_B004C44N58 |title=The trains of the Holocaust |publisher=Kindle Edition | author=Hedi Enghelberg |year=2013 |page=63 |isbn=978-160585-123-5 |quote=[http://www.enghelberg.com/EDICIONES/trains_holocaust.htm Book excerpts] from Enghelberg.com.}}</ref>
===Scale of the need for mass transportation=== [[File:WW2-Holocaust-Europe.png|thumb|250px|right|General map of deportation routes and camps]] Following the [[Wannsee Conference]] of 1942, the Nazis began to murder the Jews in large numbers at newly built death camps of [[Operation Reinhard]]. Since 1941, the ''[[Einsatzgruppen]]'', mobile extermination squads, were already conducting mass shootings of Jews in the [[Kresy|Eastern territories]] which were occupied earlier by the [[Soviet Union]], as well as east of the 1939 Soviet borders .<ref name="Rossino-89">{{Cite book|last=Rossino|first=Alexander B.|url=http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.2307/j.ctv1rmk6w|title=Polin: Studies in Polish Jewry Volume 16: Focusing on Jewish Popular Culture and Its Afterlife|date=2003-11-01|publisher=The Littman Library of Jewish Civilization|year=|isbn=978-1-909821-67-5|editor-last=Steinlauf|editor-first=Michael C.|location=|pages=431–452|chapter=“Polish ‘Neighbours’ and German Invaders: Anti-Jewish Violence in the Białystok District during the Opening Weeks of Operation Barbarossa.”|doi=10.2307/j.ctv1rmk6w.30|editor-last2=Polonsky|editor-first2=Antony}}</ref> The Jews of Western Europe were either deported to ghettos emptied through mass killings, such as the [[Rumbula massacre]] of the inhabitants of the [[Riga Ghetto]], or sent directly to Treblinka, Belzec and Sobibór, [[extermination camps]] built in spring and summer of 1942 only for gassing. Auschwitz II Birkenau gas chambers began operating in March. The last death camp, Majdanek, began operating them in late 1942.<ref name="g-chambers">{{cite web | url=https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/Holocaust/Majdanek2.html | title=Gas Chambers at Majdanek | publisher=The American-Israeli Cooperative | work=Majdanek, Auschwitz II, Sobibor, Belzec and Treblinka | year=2009 | accessdate=11 February 2014 | author=Jewish Virtual Library}}</ref>
At Wannsee, the ''[[Schutzstaffel|SS]]'' estimated that the "Final Solution" could ultimately eradicate up to 11 million European Jews; Nazi planners envisioned the inclusion of Jews living in neutral and non-occupied countries such as [[Ireland]], [[Sweden]], [[Turkey]], and the [[United Kingdom]]. Deportations on this scale required the coordination of numerous German government ministries and state organisations, including the [[SS-Reichssicherheitshauptamt|Reich Main Security Office]] (RSHA), the Transport Ministry, and the Foreign Office. The RSHA coordinated and directed the deportations; the Transport Ministry organized train schedules; and the Foreign Office negotiated with German-allied states and their railways about "processing" their own Jews.<ref>[http://www.ushmm.org/wlc/en/article.php?ModuleId=10005445 German Railways and the Holocaust] at the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum.</ref>
In recent years, the German spokesman for the ''[http://www.zug-der-erinnerung.eu/ Train of Commemoration]'' remembrance project, Hans-Rüdiger Minow, told [[The Jerusalem Post]] that from among the World War II railway staff and officials, there is "no word about those who committed the crimes" even though 200,000 train employees were involved in the rail deportations and "10,000 to 20,000 were responsible for mass murders". The railwaymen were never prosecuted.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.jpost.com/Jewish-World/Jewish-News/No-Berlin-stop-for-Shoah-train |title=Mobile Holocaust exhibit forced to skip stop to ensure German railway system run on time |publisher=The Jerusalem Post |work=No Berlin stop for Shoah train |date=2008-04-17 |accessdate=5 February 2014 | author=Benjamin Weinthal, Berlin}}</ref>
==The journey== [[File:Deportation of Jews from Slovakia, 1942.jpg|thumb|[[Hlinka Guard]]smen force Slovak Jews onto Holocaust trains, 1942]]
The first trains with German Jews expelled to ghettos in [[occupied Poland]] began departing from central Germany on 16 October 1941.<ref name="autogenerated9">{{cite web|url=http://sg.geocities.com/raiha_evelyn/holocaust.html |title=The Holocaust |publisher=Raiha Evelyn |work=Concentration Camps & Death Camps |accessdate=4 February 2014 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090723030423/http://sg.geocities.com/raiha_evelyn/holocaust.html |archivedate=July 23, 2009 }}</ref> Called ''Sonderzüge'' (special trains),<ref name="A2A"/> the trains had low priority for the movement and would proceed to the mainline only after all other transports went through, inevitably extending transport time beyond expectations.<ref name="A2A"/>
The trains consisted of sets of either third class passenger carriages,<ref>Michael Nadel, [http://jewishmag.com/62mag/nadel/nadel.htm Recalling the Holocaust]</ref> but mainly [[goods wagon|freight car]]s or [[Stock car (rail)|cattle car]]s or both; the latter packed with up to 150 deportees, although 50 was the number proposed by the ''SS'' regulations. No food or water was supplied. The ''Güterwagen'' boxcars were fitted with only a bucket [[latrine]]. A small barred window provided irregular ventilation, which oftentimes resulted in multiple deaths from either suffocation or exposure to the elements.<ref name="autogenerated11">{{cite web|url=http://www.jewishsf.com/content/2-0-/module/displaystory/story_id/25615/edition_id/498/format/html/displaystory.html |title=Holocaust survivor gives teens the straight story |publisher=Jewish news weekly of Northern California |date=April 22, 2005 |accessdate=5 February 2014 |author=Joshua Brandt |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051126224024/http://www.jewishsf.com/content/2-0-/module/displaystory/story_id/25615/edition_id/498/format/html/displaystory.html |archivedate=November 26, 2005 }}</ref> Some freight cars had a layer of [[Calcium oxide|quick lime]] on the floor.<ref name="dcgr">[[Kurt Gerstein]], [http://www.deathcamps.org/belzec/gerstein.html "Gerstein Report" in English translation.] Tübingen, 4 May 1945.</ref>
At times, the Germans did not have enough filled cars ready to start a major shipment of Jews to the camps,<ref name=autogenerated10 /> so the victims were kept locked inside overnight at layover yards. The Holocaust trains also waited for military trains to pass.<ref name=autogenerated11 /> An average transport took about four days. The longest transport of the war, from [[Corfu]], took 18 days. When the train arrived at the camp and the doors were opened, everyone was already dead.<ref name=autogenerated10 />
Due to delays and cramped conditions, many deportees died in transit. On 18 August 1942, ''Waffen SS'' officer [[Kurt Gerstein]] had witnessed at [[Bełżec extermination camp|Belzec]] the arrival of "45 wagons with 6,700 people, of whom 1,450 were already dead on arrival". That train came with the Jews of the [[Lwów Ghetto]],<ref name="dcgr"/> less than {{convert|100|km}} away.<ref name="H.E.206">Holocaust Encyclopedia, [http://www.ushmm.org/wlc/en/article.php?ModuleId=10007206 "Belzec: Chronology"] United States Holocaust Memorial Museum, 2013.</ref>
===Point of arrival=== [[File:Selection on the ramp at Auschwitz-Birkenau, 1944 (Auschwitz Album) 1b.jpg|link=Auschwitz Album|thumb|left|Jews from [[Carpathian Ruthenia|Carpatho-Ruthenia]] are "selected" on the ''Judenrampe'', May–June 1944. To be sent to the right meant assignment to slave labour; to the left, the [[gas chamber]]s.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.yadvashem.org/yv/en/exhibitions/album_Auschwitz/index.asp |title=The Auschwitz Album |publisher=[[Yad Vashem]] |accessdate=4 February 2014}}</ref>]]
The ''SS'' built three [[extermination camp]]s in occupied Poland specifically for Operation Reinhard: [[Bełżec extermination camp|Bełżec]], [[Sobibór]], and [[Treblinka]]. They were fitted with identical mass killing installations disguised as communal shower rooms.<ref name="YV-AR724">{{cite web |author=Yad Vashem |title=Aktion Reinhard |url=http://www.yadvashem.org/odot_pdf/microsoft%20word%20-%205724.pdf |via=direct download 33.1 KB |publisher=Shoah Resource Center, The International School for Holocaust Studies |year=2013 |accessdate=6 April 2014 }}</ref> In addition, gas chambers were developed in 1942 at the [[Majdanek concentration camp]],<ref name="YV-AR724"/> and at [[Auschwitz concentration camp#Auschwitz II-Birkenau|Auschwitz II-Birkenau]].<ref name="YV-AR724"/><ref name="Grossman">{{cite web |last=Grossman |first=Vasily |authorlink=Vasily Grossman |year=1946 |title=The Treblinka Hell |publisher=Foreign Languages Publishing House |at=''[http://dl.dropbox.com/u/47875651/TheHellOfTreblinka.html (online)]'' |location=Moscow |url=http://msuweb.montclair.edu/~furrg/essays/grossmantreblinka46.pdf |via=direct download 2.14 MB |accessdate=6 April 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006123821/http://msuweb.montclair.edu/~furrg/essays/grossmantreblinka46.pdf |archive-date=6 October 2014 |url-status=dead }}</ref> In the German-occupied USSR, at the [[Maly Trostinets extermination camp]], shootings were used to kill victims in the woods.<ref name="Yad Vashem636">{{cite web |url=http://www.yadvashem.org/odot_pdf/microsoft%20word%20-%206636.pdf |title=Maly Trostinets |publisher=Shoah Resource Center, The International School for Holocaust Studies |year=2013 |accessdate=1 September 2013 |author=Yad Vashem |via=direct download, 19.5 KB}}</ref> At [[Chełmno extermination camp|Chelmno]], victims were killed in [[Nazi gas van|gas van]]s, whose redirected exhaust fed into sealed compartments at the rear of the vehicle. These were used at Trostinets as well.<ref name="ppu.org">{{cite web |title=The genocide: 1942 (Chelmno, Maly Trostinets) |url=http://www.ppu.org.uk/genocide/g_holocaust1.html |publisher=Peace Pledge Union |accessdate=6 April 2014 }}</ref> Neither of these two camps had international rail connections; therefore, the trains stopped at the nearby ghettos [[Łódź Ghetto|in Łódź]] and [[Minsk Ghetto|in Minsk]], respectively.<ref name="ARC2005"/> From there, the prisoners were taken by trucks.<ref name="ARC2005">{{cite web |title=Maly Trostinec |quote=Maly Trostinec most closely resembled Chelmno, although at Maly Trostinec, murder was principally committed by shooting. |url=http://www.deathcamps.org/occupation/maly%20trostinec.html |publisher=ARC 2005 |accessdate=6 April 2014 }}</ref><ref name="HEART2008">{{cite web |author1=Chris Webb |author2=Carmelo Liscioto |title=Maly Trostinets. The Death Camp near Minsk |quote=Jews were killed by means of mobile gas chambers... and shot to death in front of pits, 50 meters long and 3 metres deep. |publisher=Holocaust Research Project.org 2008 |url=http://www.holocaustresearchproject.org/nazioccupation/malytrost.html |accessdate=6 April 2014 }}</ref> At Treblinka, Belzec, and Sobibor, the killing mechanism consisted of a large internal-combustion engine delivering exhaust fumes to gas chambers through pipes.<ref name="Arad87">{{Cite book |ref=harv |last=Arad |first=Yitzhak |authorlink=Yitzhak Arad |title=Belzec, Sobibor, Treblinka. The Operation Reinhard Death Camps |year=1987 |publisher=Indiana University Press |location=Bloomington, Indianapolis |isbn=978-0-253-21305-1 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QpAgHYTPRz0C |via=Google Books, preview |page=31 |quote= Testimony of ''SS Scharführer'' Erich Fuchs in the Sobibor-Bolender trial, Düsseldorf.}}</ref> At Auschwitz and Majdanek, the gas chambers relied on [[Zyklon B]] pellets of hydrogen cyanide, poured through vents in the roof from cans sealed hermetically.<ref name="Arad87"/><ref name="Piper"/>
Once off the transports, the prisoners were split by category. The old, the young, the sick and the infirm were sometimes separated for immediate death by shooting, while the rest were prepared for the gas chambers. In a single 14-hour workday, 12,000 to 15,000<ref name="A.W.">{{cite book |author=Alex Woolf |title=A Short History of the World |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lyMEAwAAQBAJ&pg=PT637 |year=2008 |isbn=9781848588721 }}</ref> people would be killed at any one of these camps.<ref name="Arad87"/><ref name="JVL-Reinhard5">{{cite web |author=McVay, Kenneth |title=The Construction of the Treblinka Extermination Camp |url=https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/Holocaust/reinhard.html#5 |publisher=Jewish Virtual Library.org |work=Yad Vashem Studies, XVI |year=1984 |accessdate=3 November 2013}}</ref> The capacity of the crematoria at Birkenau was 20,000 bodies per day.<ref name="Piper">{{cite book |last=Piper |first=Franciszek |editor1-last=Gutman |editor1-first=Yisrael |editor2-last=Berenbaum |editor2-first=Michael |title=Anatomy of the Auschwitz Death Camp |chapter=Gas Chambers and Crematoria |pages=[https://archive.org/details/anatomyofauschwi00yisr/page/169 169–170] |year=1994 |publisher=Indiana University Press |location=Bloomington, Indiana |isbn=978-0-253-32684-3 |url=https://archive.org/details/anatomyofauschwi00yisr/page/169 }}</ref><ref name="Friedlander">{{cite book |last=Friedlander |first=Saul |title=The Years of Extermination |publisher=HarperCollins |location=New York |year=2009 |isbn=978-0-06-198000-8 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7KaCGDUys50C |ref=harv}}</ref> The new arrivals who looked healthy were selected for [[Extermination through labor|slave labor]] in the ''[[Sonderkommando]]s'', burying victims in mass graves and burning corpses under pain of death.<ref name=autogenerated9/>
==The calculations== [[File:US Holocaust Memorial Museum - Boxcar.jpg|thumb|Interior of a [[boxcar]] used to transport [[History of the Jews during World War II|Jews]] and other [[Holocaust victims]] during [[World War II]], the [[United States Holocaust Memorial Museum]] in Washington, D.C.]]
The standard means of delivery was a 10-metre long [[Goods wagon|freight car]], although third class [[Passenger car (rail)|passenger carriages]] were also used when the ''SS'' wanted to keep up the "resettlement to work in the East" myth, particularly in the Netherlands and in Belgium. The ''SS'' manual covered such trains, suggesting a carrying capacity per each trainset of 2,500 people in 50 cars, each boxcar loaded with 50 prisoners. In reality, however, boxcars were routinely loaded to 200% of capacity, or 100 people per car.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ndUAAQAAQBAJ |title=The United States Holocaust Memorial Museum Encyclopedia of Camps and Ghettos, 1933-1945 |publisher=Indiana University Press |year=2009 |accessdate=4 February 2014 |author=Geoffrey P. Megargee |page=1514 |isbn=978-0253003508}}</ref> This resulted in an average of 5,000 people per trainset. Notably, during the [[Grossaktion Warsaw (1942)|mass deportation of Jews]] from the [[Warsaw Ghetto]] to [[Treblinka]] in 1942, trains carried up to 7,000 victims each.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.yadvashem.org/yv/en/exhibitions/this_month/resources/treblinka.asp |title=Treblinka: Railway Transports |publisher=Yad Vashem |work=This Month in Holocaust History |accessdate=4 February 2014 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141008222515/http://www.yadvashem.org/yv/en/exhibitions/this_month/resources/treblinka.asp |archivedate=8 October 2014 }}</ref>
In total, over 1,600 trains were organised by the German Transport Ministry, and logged mainly by the Polish state railway company taken over by Germany, due to the majority of death camps being located in occupied Poland.<ref name=autogenerated13>[http://www.writing.upenn.edu/~afilreis/Holocaust/black.html Edwin Black on IBM and the Holocaust]</ref> Between 1941 and December 1944, the official date of the closing of the Auschwitz-Birkenau complex, the transport/arrival timetable was 1.5 trains per day: 50 freight cars × 50 prisoners per freight car × 1,066 days = ~4,000,000 prisoners in total.<ref name="Enghelberg"/>
On 20 January 1943, [[Heinrich Himmler|Himmler]] sent a letter to [[Albert Ganzenmüller]], the Under-secretary of State at the Reich Transport Ministry, requesting: "need your help and support. If I am to wind things up quickly, I must have more trains."<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|url=http://www.neveragain.org/1943.htm |title=The Holocaust timeline: 1943 |publisher=NeverAgain.org, Internet Archive |accessdate=5 February 2014 |author=NAAF Project |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060822061740/http://www.neveragain.org/1943.htm |archivedate=August 22, 2006 }}</ref> Of the estimated 6 million Jews exterminated during World War II, 2 million were murdered on the spot by the military, [[Waffen-SS|political police]], and mobile death squads of the ''[[Einsatzgruppen]]'' aided by the [[Ordnungspolizei#Police Battalions|Orpo battalions]] and their [[Hiwi (volunteer)|auxiliaries]]. The remainder were shipped to their deaths elsewhere.
===Payment=== Most of the Jews were forced to pay for their own deportations, particularly wherever passenger carriages were used. This payment came in the form of direct money deposit to the ''SS'' in light of the "resettlement to work in the East" myth. Charged in the ghettos for accommodation, adult Jews paid full price one-way tickets, while children under 10–12 years of age paid half price, and those under four went free. Jews who had run out of money were the first to be deported.<ref name="RJB57"/>
The ''SS'' forwarded part of this money to the German Transport Authority to pay the German Railways for transport of the Jews. The ''[[Deutsche Reichsbahn-Gesellschaft|Reichsbahn]]'' was paid the equivalent of a third class railway ticket for every prisoner transported to his or her destination: 8,000,000 passengers, 4 [[Pfennig]] per track kilometer, times 600 km (average voyage length), equaled 240 million [[German Reichsmark|Reichsmark]]s.<ref name="A2A">{{cite book |title=Approaches to Auschwitz |author1=Richard L. Rubenstein |author2=John K. Roth |publisher=Westminster John Knox Press |year=2003 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IfoBx6skMCkC |via=Google Books, search inside |page=362|isbn=9780664223533 }}</ref>
{{multiple image | direction = vertical | width = 250 | image1 = Steam locomotive RN 52 4867.JPG | caption1 = German-made [[DRB Class 52]] steam locomotive used by the ''Deutsche Reichsbahn'' during World War II. Members of this class were used in the Holocaust.<ref name="USHMM-media">{{cite AV media |people=Claude Lanzmann Shoah Collection |date=July 1978 |title=Henryk Gawkowski and Treblinka railway workers |medium=Camera Rolls #4-7 |language=Polish, French |url=http://www.ushmm.org/online/film/display/detail.php?file_num=5271 |access-date=8 September 2015 |via=Clips viewable online |time=02:10:59 and 07:10:16 |location=USHMM, Washington, DC |publisher=Steven Spielberg Film and Video Archive |id=ID: 3362-3372 }}</ref> | image2 = Pt31-64 Chabówka (Nemo5576).jpg | caption2 = Polish-made Pt31-64 steam locomotive produced by [[H. Cegielski – Poznań]] in the interwar [[Second Polish Republic]]. Members of this class were used by Nazi Germany for deportation actions.<ref name="Bujniewicz"/> }}
The ''Reichsbahn'' pocketed both this money and its own share of the cash paid by the transported Jews after the ''SS'' fees. According to an expert report established on behalf of the German "Train of Commemoration" project, the receipts taken in by the state-owned ''Deutsche Reichsbahn'' for mass deportations in the period between 1938 and 1945 reached a sum of US $664,525,820.34.<ref name="xyqom-Gutachten">{{cite book |url=http://xyqom.org/zde/Gutachten.pdf|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222145340/http://xyqom.org/zde/Gutachten.pdf |url-status=dead |archive-date=2014-02-22 |title=Expert Report on the Deutsche Reichsbahn's Receipts |publisher=Train of Commemoration Registered, Non-Profit Association, Berlin |work=Obtained during the Nazi Dictatorship for Services in Transporting Persons from the German Reich and Occupied Areas of Europe to Concentration Camps |date=November 2009 |accessdate=4 February 2014 |author=Train of Commemoration |language=German, English, French, Polish |via=direct download 740 KB from Wayback Machine |quote=With payment summaries, tables and literature.}}</ref>
==Operations across Europe== Powered mainly by efficient steam locomotives, the Holocaust trains were kept to a maximum of 55 [[freight car]]s on average, loaded from 150% to 200% capacity.<ref name="Enghelberg"/> The participation of German State Railway (the ''Deutsche Reichsbahn'') was crucial to the effective implementation of the "[[Final Solution|Final Solution of the Jewish Question]]". The DRB was paid to transport Jews and other victims of the Holocaust from thousands of towns and cities throughout Europe to meet their death in the [[Nazi concentration camp]] system.<ref name="Enghelberg"/>
As well as transporting German Jews, DRB was responsible for coordinating transports on the rail networks of occupied territories and Germany's allies. The characteristics of organized concentration and transportation of victims of the Holocaust varied by country.
===Belgium=== After Germany invaded [[Belgium]] on 10 May 1940, all Jews were forced to register with the police as of 28 October 1940. The lists enabled Belgium to become the first country in occupied Western Europe to deport recently immigrating Jews.<ref name=HeartBel>{{cite web |url=http://www.holocaustresearchproject.org/nazioccupation/beligiumjews.html |title=The Destruction of the Jews of Belgium |publisher=Holocaust Education & Archive Research Team |accessdate=28 February 2014 |quote= Native-born Belgian Jews were first noticed at Auschwitz after 744 of them were received at the camp following deportation of 998 Jews from Mechelen on 5 August 1942.}}</ref> The implementation of [[The Holocaust in Belgium|the "Final Solution" in Belgium]] centred on the [[Mechelen transit camp]] (Malines) chosen because it was the hub of the [[National Railway Company of Belgium|Belgian National Railway]] system.<ref name=HeartBel/> The first convoy left Mechelen for extermination camps on 22 July 1942, although nearly 2,250 Jews had already been deported as forced laborers for {{lang|de|[[Organisation Todt]]}} to Northern France.<ref name=Yahil393>{{cite book|last=Yahil|first=Leni|title=The Holocaust: The Fate of European Jewry, 1932–1945|series=Studies in Jewish History|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=1991|location=Oxford|edition=Reprint (trans.)|isbn=978-0-19-504523-9|page=393}}</ref> By October 1942, some 16,600 people had been deported in 17 convoys. At this time, deportations were temporarily halted until January 1943.<ref name=Yahil435/><ref name=Yahil394>{{cite book|last=Yahil|first=Leni|title=The Holocaust: The Fate of European Jewry, 1932–1945|series=Studies in Jewish History|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=1991|location=Oxford|edition=Reprint (trans.)|isbn=978-0-19-504523-9|page=394}}</ref> Those deported in the first wave were not Belgian citizens, resulting from the intervention by [[Elisabeth of Bavaria, Queen of Belgium|Queen Elisabeth]] with the German authorities.<ref name=Yahil435>{{cite book|last=Yahil|first=Leni|title=The Holocaust: The Fate of European Jewry, 1932–1945|series=Studies in Jewish History|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=1991|location=Oxford|edition=Reprint (trans.)|isbn=978-0-19-504523-9|page=435}}</ref> In 1943, the deportations of Belgians resumed.
[[File:Breendonk071.jpg|thumb|left|A cattle truck used for the transport of Belgian Jews to camps in Eastern Europe. The openings were covered in barbed wire.<ref>{{cite book|last=Schreiber|first=Marion|title=The Twentieth Train: the True Story of the Ambush of the Death Train to Auschwitz|year=2003|publisher=Grove Press|location=New York|isbn=978-0-8021-1766-3|edition=1st US|page=[https://archive.org/details/twentiethtrain00mari/page/203 203]|url=https://archive.org/details/twentiethtrain00mari/page/203}}</ref> This example is preserved at [[Fort Breendonk]].]]
In September, Jews with Belgian citizenship were deported for the first time.<ref name=Yahil435/> After the war, the collaborator Felix Lauterborn stated in his trial that 80 percent of arrests in Antwerp used information from paid informants.<ref>{{cite book|last=Saerens|first=Lieven|title=De Jodenjagers van de Vlaamse SS|isbn=978-90-209-7384-6|year=2008|publisher=Lannoo|page=188}}</ref> In total, 6,000 Jews were deported in 1943, with another 2,700 in 1944. Transports were halted by the deteriorating situation in occupied Belgium before the liberation.<ref name=Yahil436>{{cite book|last=Yahil|first=Leni|title=The Holocaust: The Fate of European Jewry, 1932–1945|series=Studies in Jewish History|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=1991|location=Oxford|edition=Reprint (trans.)|isbn=978-0-19-504523-9|page=436}}</ref>
The percentages of Jews which were deported varied by location. It was highest in Antwerp, with 67 percent deported, but lower in Brussels (37 percent), Liége (35 percent) and Charleroi (42 percent).<ref>{{cite book|last=Saerens|first=Lieven|chapter=Antwerp's Attitudes towards the Jews from 1918–1940 and its Implications for the Period of Occupation|editor1-last=Michman|editor1-first=Dan|title=Belgium and the Holocaust: Jews, Belgians, Germans|year=1998|publisher=Yad Vashem|location=Jerusalem|isbn=978-965-308-068-3|edition=2nd|page=194}}</ref> The main destination for the convoys was [[Auschwitz concentration camp]] in [[General Government|occupied Poland]]. Smaller numbers were sent to [[Buchenwald concentration camp|Buchenwald]] and [[Ravensbrück concentration camp]]s, as well as [[Concentration camps in France|Vittel concentration camp]] in France.<ref name=Yahil436/> In total, 25,437 Jews were deported from Belgium.<ref name=Yahil436/> Only 1,207 of these survived the war.<ref name=telegraph1>{{cite news|last=Waterfield|first=Bruno|title=Nazi hunters call on Belgium's justice minister to be sacked|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/history/world-war-two/8518997/Nazi-hunters-call-on-Belgiums-justice-minister-to-be-sacked.html|accessdate=26 February 2013|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]|date=17 May 2011}}</ref>
The only time during World War II that a Holocaust train carrying Jewish deportees from Western Europe was stopped by the Underground happened on 19 April 1943, when the [[Twentieth convoy|Transport No. 20]] left Mechelen with 1,631 Jews, heading for Auschwitz. Soon after leaving Mechelen, the driver stopped the train after seeing an emergency red light, set by the Belgians. After a brief fire fight between the Nazi train guards and the three resistance members – equipped only with one pistol between them – the train started again. Of the 233 people who attempted to escape, 26 were shot on the spot, 89 were recaptured, and 118 got away.<ref name="bbc-train"/>{{#tag:ref|When the Twentieth convoy arrived at Auschwitz, 70% of the women and girls were gassed immediately on arrival. Sources claim that all of the remaining women from Belgian Transport No.20 were sent to Block X of Birkenau for medical experimentation.<ref name="bbc-train">{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-22188075 |title=Escaping the train to Auschwitz |authors=Althea Williams and Sarah Ehrlich |work=BBC News |date=20 April 2013 |accessdate=20 April 2013 |quote=Policeman John Aerts who helped the runaways evade recapture and return to [[Brussels]] was later declared a "Righteous Gentile" by [[Yad Vashem]] in Jerusalem. Of the three resistance workers: Robert Maistriau was arrested in March 1944, liberated from [[Bergen-Belsen concentration camp|Bergen-Belsen]] in 1945, and lived until 2008; Youra Livschitz was later captured and executed; Jean Franklemon was arrested and sent to [[Sachsenhausen concentration camp|Sachsenhausen]], liberated from there in May 1945, and died in 1977.}}</ref>}}
===Bulgaria=== {{Annotated image |float=right |width=200 |height=220 |caption=From the Holocaust Museum in [[Skopje]]; original wagon used for transport of [[History of the Jews in North Macedonia|Macedonian Jews]] |image=The Holocaust Museum in Skopje 29.JPG |annotations= |image-top=0 |image-left=-58 |image-width=340}}
Bulgaria joined the [[Axis powers]] in March 1941 and took part in the [[invasion of Yugoslavia]] and Greece.<ref name="ushmm-b">[https://web.archive.org/web/20120816204424/https://www.ushmm.org/wlc/en/article.php?ModuleId=10005355 Persecution of Jews in Bulgaria] United States Holocaust Memorial Museum, Washington, DC.</ref> The Bulgarian government set up transit camps in [[Skopje]], [[Blagoevgrad]] and [[Dupnitsa]] for the Jews from the former Serbian province of [[Vardar Banovina]] and [[Thrace]] (today's [[North Macedonia]] and [[Greece]]).<ref name="ushmm-b"/> The [[Final Solution|"deportations to the east"]] of 13,000 inmates,<ref name="prweb">{{cite web | title=International Jewish Committee Calls on Bulgaria to Clarify Their Role in the Deportation of 13,000 Jews to Treblinka | url=http://www.prweb.com/releases/2011/02/prweb5110474.htm | publisher=Vocus PRWeb | date=28 February 2011 | accessdate=23 June 2015 | author=PRWEB}}</ref> mostly to [[Treblinka extermination camp]] began on 22 February 1943, predominantly in passenger cars.<ref name="ushmm-b&t2">{{cite web |url=http://www.ushmm.org/wlc/en/article.php?ModuleId=10007257 |title=Treblinka: Chronology |publisher=United States Holocaust Memorial Museum |date=10 June 2013 |accessdate=9 December 2013 |author=Holocaust Encyclopedia |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120605123023/http://www.ushmm.org/wlc/en/article.php?ModuleId=10007257 |archivedate=5 June 2012 |via=Wayback Machine |quote=Deportations from Bulgarian-occupied territory among others. }}</ref> In four days, some 20 trainsets departed under severely overcrowded conditions to [[occupied Poland]] requiring each train to stop daily to dump the bodies of Jews who died during the previous 24 hours.<ref name=autogenerated1 /> In May 1943 the Bulgarian government led by [[Boris III of Bulgaria|King Boris III]] expelled 20,000 Jews from [[Sofia]] and at the same time, made plans to deport Bulgaria's Jews to the camps pursuant to an agreement with Germany.<ref name="ushmm-b&t2"/>
A Holocaust train from Thrace was witnessed by Archbishop Stefan of Sofia who was shocked by what he saw. His protest letter along with those of other [[Bulgarian Orthodox Church|Orthodox clergymen]] were ignored by the King.<ref name="Vassilev"/> A demonstration in Sofia on 24 May 1943 by the Jewish community led by Rabbi [[Daniel Zion]] was quashed by Bulgarian police arresting 400 Jews.<ref name="Vassilev">Rossen V. Vassilev, [http://newpol.org/content/rescue-bulgarias-jews-world-war-ii The Rescue of Bulgaria's Jews in World War II] New Politics, Winter 2010, Vol: XII-4.</ref> Luckily, a small delegation under parliamentarian [[Dimitar Peshev]] managed to launch a successful protest at the Ministry of Internal Affairs.<ref name="ushmm-b&t2"/> The new order issued by Minister [[Petar Gabrovski]] to release the Jews already rounded up, was not reversed.<ref name="Vassilev"/> His decision prevented the Jewish community of 49,000 people from being exterminated in [[death camp]]s of the [[General Government]].<ref name="Vassilev"/> Nevertheless, the Bulgarian Jews remained the subject of severe racial restrictions locally, and were stripped by the government of currency, jewelry, and gold handed over to the Bulgarian national bank.<ref>Michael Bar-Zohar, ''Beyond Hitler's grasp: the heroic rescue of Bulgaria's Jews''. Holbrook, Mass.: Adams Media, 1998. {{ISBN|1-58062-060-4}}. [http://www.abebooks.com/9781580620604/Beyond-Hitlers-Grasp-Heroic-Rescue-1580620604/plp Review.]</ref> According to Bulgarian historian Nissan Oren, King Boris did not show any humanitarian inclinations for the Jews of his country, and the later claims of his benevolence are without firm foundation.<ref name="jewishvirtuallibrary">Jewish Virtual Library, [https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/vjw/bulgaria.html World War II & the Holocaust] Bulgaria Virtual Jewish History Tour.</ref>
===Bohemia and Moravia=== Czechoslovakia was annexed by Nazi Germany in 1939. Within the new ethnic-Czech [[Protectorate of Bohemia and Moravia]] the [[Czechoslovak State Railways]] (ČSD) were taken over by the ''Reichsbann'' and the new German railway company ''Böhmisch-Mährische Bahn'' (BMB) was set up in its place.<ref>[http://locomotives.com.pl/Passenger%20Tank%20Locomotives/OKm11.htm OKm11] at Locomotives.com.pl.</ref> The Czech human losses in World War II were considerably lower than among other nations,<ref name="Agnew"/> estimated at between 36,000 and 55,000 with a positive growth ratio due to rising birthrate,<ref name="Agnew"/> except for the Jews. One entire town was turned into a walled-off ghetto in 1941, and named [[Theresienstadt concentration camp|Theresienstadt]] (Terezín). In all, it contained around 50,000 Jews from the Protectorate, and 37,000 from the Reich, with the remaining 20,000 Jews transported to other camps. Three-quarters of Bohemian and Moravian Jews were murdered in the Holocaust,<ref name="Agnew">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Db76shTEM60C&pg=pa1942 |title=The Czechs and the Lands of the Bohemian Crown |publisher=Hoover Press |year=2004 |author=Hugh LeCaine Agnew |pages=215, 1942 |isbn=978-0817944926}}</ref> of whom 33,000 died in Terezín.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.holocaustchronicle.org/StaticPages/282.html |title=The Holocaust Chronicle |publisher=Publications International |work=Roots of the Holocaust, Prologue: p. 282 |year=2009 |accessdate=16 February 2014}}</ref> The remainder were transported in Holocaust trains from Theresienstadt mainly to Auschwitz-Birkenau. The last train for Birkenau left Theresienstadt on 28 October 1944 with 2,038 Jews of whom 1,589 were immediately gassed.<ref name=autogenerated3>[https://web.archive.org/web/19990221184431/http://www.neveragain.org/1944.htm NAAF Holocaust Project Timeline: 1944.] NAAF Holocaust Project.</ref>
===France=== [[File:Lager Les Milles. Gedenkwaggon. Viehtransporter zum Abtransport der Juden.JPG|thumb|right|The Holocaust "Güterwagen" boxcars used by [[Camp des Milles|Milles]] and [[Drancy internment camp]]s in France]] The French national [[SNCF]] railway company under the [[Vichy France|Vichy Government]] played its part in the "Final Solution". In total, the Vichy government deported more than 76,000 Jews,<ref name="US Senate">{{cite web |url=http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/CHRG-112shrg76040/pdf/CHRG-112shrg76040.pdf |title=Holocaust-Era Claims in the 21st Century, Hearing |publisher=United States Senate |work=One Hundred Twelfth Congress, Second Session |date=20 June 2012 |accessdate=6 February 2014 |author=Committee on the Judiciary |page=4 (8 / 196) |via=direct download 2.58 MB}}</ref> without food or water (pleaded for by the Red Cross in vain),<ref name="US Senate"/> as well as thousands of other so-called undesirables to German-built concentration and extermination camps aboard the Holocaust trains, pursuant to an agreement with the German government; fewer than 3 percent survived the deportations.<ref name="EinaudiRajsfus">J.-L. Einaudi and Maurice Rajsfus, ''Les silences de la police—16 July 1942 and 17 October 1961'', ''[[L'Esprit frappeur]]'', 2001, {{ISBN|2-84405-173-1}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/europe/article5057976.ece|title=Vichy gets chance to lay ghost of Nazi past as France hosts summit|newspaper=The Times|date=2008-11-01|accessdate=2008-11-01 | location=London | first=Charles | last=Bremner}}</ref> According to [[Serge and Beate Klarsfeld|Serge Klarsfeld]], president of the organization [[Sons and Daughters of Jewish Deportees from France]], SNCF was forced by German and Vichy authorities to cooperate in providing transport for French Jews to the border and did not make any profit from this transport.<ref name="Klarsfeld2012">{{cite web|url=http://www.memorialdelashoah.com/attachments/article/77/Serge_Klarsfeld_sen_judiciary_comm_sncf_washington_july_2012.pdf |title=Analysis of Statements Made During the June 20, 2012 Hearing of the U.S. Senate Committee of the Judiciary |author=Serge Klarsfeld |date=26 June 2012 |work=Memorial de la Shoah |accessdate=19 November 2013 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131202221852/http://www.memorialdelashoah.com/attachments/article/77/Serge_Klarsfeld_sen_judiciary_comm_sncf_washington_july_2012.pdf |archivedate=2 December 2013 }}</ref> However, in December 2014, SNCF agreed to pay up to $60 million worth of compensation to Holocaust survivors in the United States.<ref name="washingtonpost.com">[https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/france-to-compensate-american-holocaust-survivors/2014/12/05/9fd176c6-7c94-11e4-84d4-7c896b90abdc_story.html France to compensate American Holocaust survivors]</ref> It corresponds to approximately $100,000 per survivor.<ref>[[Le Monde]], ''Pour le rôle de la SNCF dans la Shoah, Paris va verser 100 000 euros à chaque déporté américain'' [http://www.lemonde.fr/ameriques/article/2014/12/05/etats-unis-paris-va-indemniser-les-victimes-de-la-shoah-transportees-par-la-sncf_4535530_3222.html]</ref>
[[Drancy internment camp]] served as the main transport hub for the Paris area and regions west and south thereof until August 1944, under the command of [[Alois Brunner]] from Austria.<ref>{{cite news|first=Jon |last=Henley |title=French court strikes blow against fugitive Nazi |url=http://guardian.co.uk/nazis/article/0,2763,445717,00.html |newspaper=The Guardian |date=2003-03-03 |accessdate=2014-02-06 |location=London |quote=France condemned Brunner to death ''[[trial in absentia|in absentia]]'' in 1954 for [[crimes against humanity]]. He is still wanted. |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071012183308/http://guardian.co.uk/nazis/article/0%2C2763%2C445717%2C00.html |archivedate=October 12, 2007 }}</ref> By 3 February 1944, 67 trains had left from there for Birkenau.<ref name=autogenerated3 /> [[Vittel]] internment camp served the northeast, closer to the German border from where all transports were taken over by German agents. By 23 June 1943, 50,000 Jews had been deported from France, a pace that the Germans deemed too slow.<ref name=autogenerated4>[https://web.archive.org/web/19990428154529/http://www.neveragain.org/1943a.htm NAAF Holocaust Project Timeline 1943 Continued.] NeverAgain.org.</ref> The last train from France left Drancy on 31 July 1944 with over 300 children.<ref name=autogenerated3 />
===Greece=== [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 101I-168-0894-21A, Griechenland, Saloniki, Erfassung von Juden.jpg|thumb|right|July 1942 selection of Jews in [[Thessaloniki]].<ref>Yitschak Kerem, ''Le Monde sépharade'', Volume I, p. 924–933. Paris: Éditions du Seuil, 2006. {{ISBN|2020869926}}.</ref>]] [[File:Train tickets of Greek Jews Auchwitz-Birkenau Museum.jpg|thumb|right|Train tickets of Greek Jews deported to Auschwitz-Birkenau for extermination displayed at the museum in the former Auschwitz I camp.]] After [[Battle of Greece|the invasion]], Greece was divided between the Italian, Bulgarian, and the German zones of occupation until September 1943. Most Greek Jews lived in [[Thessaloniki]] (Salonika) ruled by Germany, where the collection camp was set up for the Jews also from [[Athens]] and [[List of islands of Greece|the Greek Islands]]. From there 45,000–50,000 Jews were sent to Auschwitz-Birkenau between March and August 1943, packed 80 to a wagon. There were also 13,000 Greek Jews in the Italian, and 4,000 Jews in the Bulgarian zone of occupation. In September 1943, the Italian zone was taken over by the Third Reich.
Overall, some 60,000–65,000 Greek Jews were deported in Holocaust trains by the ''SS'' to Auschwitz, Majdanek, Dachau and the subcamps of Mauthausen before the war's end,<ref name=autogenerated14>[http://www.ushmm.org/wlc/article.php?lang=en&ModuleId=10005372 Deportations to Killing Centers]</ref><ref name="umass"/> including over 90% of Thessaloniki's prewar population of 50,000 Jews. Of these, 5,000 Jews were deported to [[Treblinka]] from the regions of [[Thrace]] and from [[Macedonia (Greece)|Macedonia]] in the Bulgarian share of the partitioned Greece, where they were gassed upon arrival.<ref name="umass">{{cite journal |url=https://www.umass.edu/judaic/anniversaryvolume/articles/30-F3-Bowman.pdf |title=The Jews in Greece |journal=Minorities in Greece: Aspects of a Plural Society |year=2002 |accessdate=18 February 2014 |author=Steven Bowman |page=9 of current document (427) |via=direct download |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130701203458/http://www.umass.edu/judaic/anniversaryvolume/articles/30-F3-Bowman.pdf |archivedate=1 July 2013 }}</ref><ref name="Danish Center">{{cite web|url=http://www.holocaust-education.dk/holocaust/deportationer.asp |title=Deportations from the Balkans |publisher=The Danish Center for Holocaust and Genocide Studies |work=Holocaust Education: Deportations |year=2002 |accessdate=18 February 2014 |author1=Peter Vogelsang |author2=Brian B. M. Larsen |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140416061232/http://www.holocaust-education.dk/holocaust/deportationer.asp |archivedate=16 April 2014 }}</ref>
===Hungary=== Under Hungarian control the number of Jews grew to a total of 725,007 officially by 1941. Some 184,453 of them lived in Budapest.<ref name="Kraus">Naftali Kraus, [http://www.porges.net/JewishHistoryOfHungary.html Holocaust Period.] ''Jewish History of Hungary''.</ref> While in alliance with Nazi Germany, Hungary acquired new provinces at both [[First Vienna Award|the First]] and the [[Second Vienna Award]]s (1938; 1940). The [[Hungarian Army]] received vital help from the [[Hungarian State Railways]] (MÁV) in [[Northern Transylvania]] (Erdély).<ref name="lib">Librarian (10 Sep 2006), [http://www.ww2incolor.com/forum/showthread.php/3458-Hungarian-military-in-WWII Hungarian military in WWII.] ''Bulletin'', Senta, Serbia.</ref> The non-native Jews were expelled from the Hungarian territory; some 20,000 of them were transported to occupied Czechoslovakia and [[Yugoslavia]], while the [[Transylvania]]n Jews were sent back to Romania.<ref name="porges">{{cite web |url=http://www.porges.net/JewishHistoryOfHungary.html |title=Jewish History of Hungary |publisher=Porges.net |author=Naftali Kraus |year=2014 |accessdate=24 February 2014}}</ref> Hungary took part in [[Operation Barbarossa]], supplying 50,000 [[Forced labour under German rule during World War II|Jewish slave labour]] for the Eastern Front.
