Most of the workers were dead by January 1943. Later that year, Hitler discovered that Prime Minister Miklos [[Miklós Kállay|Kállay]] secretly conferred with the Western Allies. To stop him, Germany launched the [[Operation Margarethe]] in March 1944, and took over control of all Jewish affairs.<ref name="Kraus"/> On 29 April 1944, the first deportation of Hungarian Jews to Birkenau took place.<ref name=autogenerated3 /> Between 15–25 May according to ''SS-Brigadeführer'' [[Edmund Veesenmayer]] 138,870 Jews had been deported. On 31 May 1944, Veesenmayer reported additional 60,000 Jews sent to the camps in six days, while the total for the past 16 days stood at 204,312 victims.<ref name=autogenerated3 /> Between May and July 1944, helped by Hungarian police, the German ''[[Sicherheitspolizei]]'' deported nearly 440,000 Hungarian Jews mostly to Auschwitz-Birkenau,<ref name="USHMM Europe">{{cite web |url=https://www.ushmm.org/wlc/en/article.php?ModuleId=10005405 |title=Deportations to Killing Centers: Central Europe |publisher=United States Holocaust Memorial Museum, Washington, DC |work=Holocaust Encyclopedia |date=May 11, 2012 |accessdate=24 February 2014 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120816063752/https://www.ushmm.org/wlc/en/article.php?ModuleId=10005405 |archivedate=August 16, 2012 }}</ref><ref name="Hungary/Yad Vashem">Yad Vashem, [http://www.yadvashem.org/yv/en/holocaust/about/09/hungary.asp Hungarian Jewry] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131021094155/http://www.yadvashem.org/yv/en/holocaust/about/09/hungary.asp |date=2013-10-21}} at ''Holocaust History''.</ref> or 437,000 at the rate of 6,250 per day.<ref name=autogenerated3 /> [[File:Kőszeg Holokauszt kiállítás 2011.JPG|thumb|right|Holocaust train from Hungary, exhibition]]
Approximately 320,000 Hungarian Jews are estimated to have been murdered at Auschwitz-Birkenau before July 1944.<ref name=ARaw>{{cite book |title=Auschwitz: The Nazi Solution |author=Andrew Rawson |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=izigBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA69 |publisher=Pen and Sword |year=2015 |isbn=978-1473855410 |pages=69, 87, 123 |quote=While the numbers considerably reduced through June and July [1944], nearly 440,000 Hungarian Jews were transported to Auschwitz in less than eight weeks; 320,000 were murdered. — [https://books.google.com/books?id=9zegBwAAQBAJ&lpg=PP1&pg=PT144 Rawson, 144.]}} ''Also in:'' {{cite web |title=The Destruction of the Jews of Hungary |year=2007 |author1=S.J. |author2=Carmelo Lisciotto |url=http://www.holocaustresearchproject.org/othercamps/DestructionofHungarianJews.html |publisher=H.E.A.R.T |quote=Of the 381,600 Jews who left Hungary between 15 May 1944 and 30 June 1944 it is probable that 200,000 – 240,000 were gassed or shot on 46 working days.}}</ref> On 8 July, the deportation of Jews from Hungary had stopped due to international pressure by the [[Pope Pius XII|Pope]], the [[Gustaf V of Sweden|King of Sweden]], and the [[International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement|Red Cross]] (all of whom had recently learned about the extent of it).<ref name=autogenerated3 /> However, in October 1944 some 50,000 Jews were forced on a [[death march]] to Germany following a [[coup d'état]] which put the Hungarian pro-Nazi government back in control. They were forced to dig anti-tank ditches on the road westward. A further 25,000 Jews were put in an "international ghetto" under Swedish protection engineered by [[Carl Lutz]] and [[Raoul Wallenberg]]. When the Soviet Army liberated Budapest on 17 January 1945, of the original 825,000 Jews in the country,<ref name="JVL/Hungary">Rebecca Weiner, [https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/vjw/Hungary.html Hungary Virtual Jewish History Tour] ''Jewish Virtual Library''.</ref> less than 260,000 Jews were still alive,<ref name="JVL/Hungary"/><ref>David Kranzler, [http://www.holocaust-trc.org/trains.htm The Man Who Stopped the Trains to Auschwitz: George Mantello, El Salvador, and Switzerland's Finest Hour.] {{page needed|date=February 2014}}</ref> including 80,000 Hungarian natives.<ref name="ind09/96">{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/hungarys-jews-marvel-at-their-golden-future-1361842.html|title=Hungary's Jews Marvel at Their Golden Future |last=Bridge|first=Adrian|date=1996-09-05|newspaper=The Independent|accessdate=2014-02-27|location=London}}</ref><ref>Peter Vogelsang & Brian B. M. Larsen, [http://www.holocaust-education.dk/holocaust/deportationer.asp Deportations.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140416061232/http://www.holocaust-education.dk/holocaust/deportationer.asp |date=2014-04-16 }} The Danish Center for Holocaust and Genocide Studies.</ref>
{{further|Kastner train}} One Hungarian passenger train later known as the [[Kastner train]] transported 1,684 Jews to safety in Switzerland on 30 June 1944 in exchange for gold, diamonds and cash.<ref name="bb" /> It was organized by the Hungarian journalist and lawyer [[Rudolph Kastner]], the ''de facto'' leader of the [[Zionism|Zionist]] [[Aid and Rescue Committee]] (''Vaada''). For reasons that are still disputed, the Nazi officials under [[Adolf Eichmann]] sold them exit visas in exchange for 6.5 million [[Hungarian pengő|pengő]] ([[Reichsmark|RM]] 4,000,000 or $1,600,000).<ref name=Hilberg903 /><ref>Braham, Randolph (2004): Rescue Operations in Hungary: Myths and Realities, ''East European Quarterly'' 38(2): 173–203.</ref> In their secret negotiations with the ''SS'', ''Vaada'' compiled a list of "paying persons" including prominent individuals, Orthodox Jews, Zionists and known refugees,<ref name=Hilberg903 /> as well as some 600 Jews who held [[Mandatory Palestine|Palestinian]] immigration certificates.<ref name=Hilberg903>[[Raul Hilberg|Hilberg, Raul]]. ''[[The Destruction of the European Jews]]'', Yale University Press, 2003, p. 903</ref> The list also controversially included 388 people from Kastner's home town of [[Cluj-Napoca|Cluj]].<ref name="bb">Braham, p.48; Bauer, p.197.</ref>{{#tag:ref|Although Kastner was later criticised for putting his own family on the train, [[Hansi Brand]], a member of the ''Vaada'' testified at Eichmann's trial in [[Jerusalem]] in 1961 that Kastner had included his family to reassure the others that the train was safe, and was not destined, as they feared, for Auschwitz.<ref>Bauer, Yehuda (1994): Jews for Sale?, Yale University Press, {{ISBN|0-300-05913-2}}.</ref><ref>Bilsky, Leora (2004): Transformative Justice : Israeli Identity on Trial (Law, Meaning, and Violence), University of Michigan Press, {{ISBN|0-472-03037-X}}</ref>|group=note}}
{{further|Hungarian Gold Train}} The fascist government of [[Ferenc Szálasi]] issued a decree in April 1944 ordering all Jews under the Hungarian jurisdiction to "deposit" with the authorities their gems, gold jewellery, items made with the use of precious metals, and all valuables including Oriental carpets, silver, furs, paintings and fine furniture.<ref>[http://govinfo.library.unt.edu/pcha/goldtrainfinaltoconvert.html The mystery of the Hungarian 'gold train'.] Eyelatch/Iwaniec Associates</ref> These valuables were laden on a train consisting of 44 cars sent westward ahead of the Soviet advance. This train was seized in May 1945 by U.S. occupation troops in Austria. The Hungarian escort pushed the train into a tunnel near Boeckstein where it was found by the Americans who took control of the railway station in [[Werfen]]. Two Hungarian lorries were seized in the French sector. The goods were stored in [[Salzburg]]. After household items were given to furnish American families, the remainder was repatriated to America, where, in June 1948, it was sold at Parke-Bernet Galleries in [[New York City]].<ref name="JVL-goldtrain"/>{{#tag:ref|To date, of the 1,176 paintings on the Gold Train originally stored by the U.S. Army, only one has been repatriated.<ref name="JVL-goldtrain">[https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/Holocaust/goldtrain.html#HistoryoftheGoldTrain The Mystery of the Hungarian "Gold Train"] Jewish Virtual Library.</ref> On 30 September 2005, the U.S. Government reached agreement with the representatives of the Hungarian Jewish community to pay $25.5 million in compensation with additional $500,000 for the creation of archives preserving documents associated with the Gold Train, and to declassify any remaining documents related to it.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20101126140920/http://claimscon.org/?url=news%2Fhgt "Gold Train" Settlement Will Fund Services for Hungarian Holocaust Survivors; Objections, Exclusions Due August 1, 2005.]</ref>|group=note}}
===Italy=== {{Annotated image |float=right |width=260 |height=150 |caption=Italian Holocaust train exhibition, [[Verona]] |image=Giorno memoria Verona.jpg |annotations= |image-top=-140 |image-left=-100 |image-width=500 }}
The popular view that [[Benito Mussolini]] resisted the deportation of Italian Jews to Germany is widely seen as simplistic by Jewish scholars,<ref name="Kevane">{{cite web |url=http://forward.com/articles/139293/a-wall-of-indifference-italy-s-shoah-memorial/ |title=A Wall of Indifference: Italy's Shoah Memorial |publisher=The Jewish Daily Forward.com |date=June 29, 2011 |accessdate=16 April 2014 |author=Bridget Kevane}}</ref> because the Italian Jewish community of 47,000 constituted the most assimilated Jews in Europe.<ref name="Brownfeld">{{cite web |url=http://www.acjna.org/acjna/articles_detail.aspx?id=300 |title=The Italian Holocaust: The Story of an Assimilated Jewish Community |publisher=The American Council For Judaism |date=Fall 2003 |accessdate=16 April 2014 |author=Egill Brownfeld |work=Jewish Fascists and Anti-Fascists}}</ref> About one out of every three Jewish males were members of the Fascist Party before the war began; more than 10,000 Jews who used to conceal their identity,<ref name="Brownfeld"/> because antisemitism was part of the very ideal of ''italianità'' wrote Wiley Feinstein.<ref name="Adler">{{cite journal |url=http://muse.jhu.edu/journals/hgs/summary/v020/20.3adler.html |title=''The Civilization of the Holocaust in Italy: Poets, Artists, Saints, Anti-Semites'' by Wiley Feinstein |journal=Book Review |volume=20 |issue=3 |pages=518–520 |date=Winter 2006 |accessdate=16 April 2014 |author=Franklin Hugh Adler}}</ref>
The Holocaust came to Italy in September 1943 after the German takeover of the country due to its [[Armistice of Cassibile|total capitulation at Cassibile]].<ref name="Adler"/> By February 1944, the Germans shipped 8,000 Jews to Auschwitz-Birkenau via Austria and Switzerland,<ref name="H.Enc.">{{cite web |url=http://www.ushmm.org/wlc/en/article.php?ModuleId=10005372 |title=Southern Europe |publisher=United States Holocaust Memorial Museum |work=Deportations to Killing Centers |date=June 10, 2013 |accessdate=16 April 2014 |author=Holocaust Encyclopedia}}</ref> although more than half of the victims arrested and deported from northern Italy were rounded up by the Italian police and not by the Nazis.<ref name="Kevane"/> Also between September 1943 and April 1944, at least 23,000 Italian soldiers were deported to work as slaves in German war industry, while over 10,000 partisans were captured and deported during the same period to Birkenau. By 1944, there were over half a million Italians working inside the Nazi war machine.<ref name=autogenerated12>Frontline, [https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/shows/nazis/train/ Switzerland: The Train.] PBS.org</ref>
===Netherlands=== The Netherlands was invaded on 10 May 1940 and fell under the German military control. The community of native-Dutch Jews including the new Jewish refugees from Germany and Austria was estimated at 140,000.<ref>Jewish Virtual Library, [https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/vjw/netherlands.html Netherlands (Holland): The Holocaust Era.] Encyclopedia Judaica.</ref> Most natives were concentrated in the [[Amsterdam]] ghetto before being moved to [[Westerbork transit camp]] in the north-east near the German border. Deportees for "resettlement" leaving aboard the [[Nederlandse Spoorwegen|NS]] passenger and freight trains were unaware of their final destination or fate,<ref>Yad Vashem, [http://www.yadvashem.org/yv/en/holocaust/about/09/europe_gallery.asp Deportation train from Westerbork, Holland] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140305011541/http://www.yadvashem.org/yv/en/holocaust/about/09/europe_gallery.asp |date=2014-03-05 }}. Photo Archives 43253.</ref> as postcards were often thrown from moving trains.<ref name="der Boom">Van der Boom (1 May 2007), [https://web.archive.org/*/http://www.leidenuniv.nl/en/researcharchive/index.php3-m=&c=315.htm Holocaust in the Netherlands: 'We really had no idea'.] Leiden University. Review of ''Tegen beter weten in'' by Ies Vuijsje's.</ref>
Most of the approximately 100,000 Jews sent to Westerbork perished.<ref name="der Boom"/> Between July 1942 and September 1944 almost every Tuesday a train left for Auschwitz-Birkenau and [[Sobibor extermination camp]]s, or Bergen-Belsen and [[Theresienstadt]], in a total of 94 outgoing trains. About 60,000 prisoners were sent to Auschwitz and 34,000 to Sobibor.<ref name=autogenerated14 /><ref>Holocaust Encyclopedia, [http://www.ushmm.org/wlc/en/article.php?ModuleId=1000521 Westerbork.] {{dead link|date=April 2017|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} United States Holocaust Memorial Museum, Washington, D.C.</ref> At liberation approximately 870 Jews remained in Westerbork. Only 5,200 deportees survived, most of them in [[Concentration camp Theresienstadt|Theresienstadt]], approximately 1980 survivors, or [[Bergen-Belsen concentration camp|Bergen-Belsen]], approximately 2050 survivors. From those on the sixty-eight transports to Auschwitz 1052 people returned, including 181 of the 3450 people taken from eighteen of the trains at [[Cosel]]. There were 18 survivors out of approximately one thousand people selected from the nineteen trains to Sobibor, the remainder were murdered on arrival. For the Netherlands, the overall survival rate among Jews who boarded the trains for all camps was 4.86 percent.<ref name=Schelvis(2004)>{{cite book|last=Schelvis|first=Jules|title=Vernietigingskamp Sobibor|url=http://www.bataafscheleeuw.nl/db/main/assortiment/index.php?book_id=80|year=1993|edition=5th. (2004)|publisher=De Bataafsche Leeuw|language=Dutch|pages=236ff|isbn=9789067076296}}</ref><ref name=autogenerated7>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/birmingham/content/articles/2005/01/14/last_train_from_belsen1_feature.shtml BBC - Birmingham - Faith - The Last Train from Belsen]</ref> On 29 September 2005, the Dutch national rail company [[Nederlandse Spoorwegen]] (NS) apologised for its role in the deportation of Jews to the death camps.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.expatica.com/actual/article.asp?subchannel_id=19&story_id=23852 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071211164905/http://www.expatica.com/actual/article.asp?subchannel_id=19&story_id=23852 |archivedate=2007-12-11 |title=Like a slow train coming |publisher=Expatica.com}}</ref>
===Norway=== {{main|Jewish deportees from Norway during World War II }} Norway surrendered to Nazi Germany on 10 June 1940. At the time, there were 1,700 Jews living in Norway. About half of them escaped to neutral Sweden. Round ups by the SS began in the fall of 1942 with support of the Norwegian police. In late November 1942, all Jews of [[Oslo]] including women and children were put on a ship requisitioned by the [[Quisling government]] and taken to [[Hamburg]], Germany. From there, they were deported to Auschwitz-Birkenau by train. In total, 770 Norwegian Jews were sent by boat to Nazi Germany between 1940 and 1945. Only two dozen survived.<ref name="ushmm/nor">{{cite web |publisher=United States Holocaust Memorial Museum |title=Norway |author=Holocaust Encyclopedia |at=Roundups of Norwegian Jews |url=http://www.ushmm.org/wlc/en/article.php?ModuleId=10005460 |accessdate=20 January 2016 |quote=[http://www.ushmm.org/learn/timeline-of-events/1942-1945/roundups-of-norwegian-jews Photographs of two deportation ships: SS Donau and SS Monte Rosa], courtesy of Oskar Mendelsohn.}}</ref>
===Poland=== [[File:Aktion Saybusch 1940.jpg|thumb|right|260px|''[[Action Saybusch]]'', 24 September 1940. Expelled Poles await transport at a railway crossing (in this photo, some members of the 129 families deported from [[Sól, Silesian Voivodeship|Dolna Sól]]).]] {{further|Occupation of Poland (1939–1945)|The Holocaust in Poland|Nazi crimes against the Polish nation}}
Following [[invasion of Poland]] in September 1939 Nazi Germany disbanded Polish National Railways ([[Polskie Koleje Państwowe|PKP]]) immediately, and handed over their assets to the ''Deutsche Reichsbahn'' in [[Silesia]], [[Greater Poland]] and in [[Pomerania]].<ref name="Wasilewski">{{cite web|url=http://old.pkp.pl/node/178 |title=25 września. Wcielenie kolei polskich na Śląsku, w Wielkopolsce i na Pomorzu do niemieckich kolei państwowych Deutsche Reichsbahn |trans-title=25 September: Absorption of Polish railways to German Reichsbahn |publisher=[[Polskie Koleje Państwowe]] PKP |year=2014 |accessdate=8 February 2014 |author=Jerzy Wasilewski |at=''[https://web.archive.org/web/20131221151609/http://old.pkp.pl/klubpkp/historia Historia kolei na terenie Polski]'' |via=[[Archive.is]], page missing from [[Wayback Machine|Wayback]] |url-status=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140208175309/http://old.pkp.pl/node/178 |archivedate=8 February 2014}}</ref> In November 1939, as soon as the semi-colonial [[General Government]] was set up in occupied central Poland, a separate branch of DRB called ''[[Ostbahn (General Government)|Generaldirektion der Ostbahn]]'' (''Kolej Wschodnia'' in Polish) was established with headquarters called GEDOB in [[Kraków]];<ref name="Wasilewski"/> all of the DRB branches existed outside Germany proper.<ref name="Gigliotti55">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bsnbugaMLCcC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q=Reichsbahn%20control%20Ostbahn&f=false |title=Resettlement |publisher=Berghahn Books |work=The Train Journey: Transit, Captivity, and Witnessing in the Holocaust |date=2009 |accessdate=21 September 2015 |author=Simone Gigliotti |pages=55 |isbn=978-1845459277}}</ref> The ''Ostbahn'' was granted {{convert|3,818|km}} of railway lines (nearly doubled by 1941) and 505 km of narrow gauge, initially.{{r|Masłowska}}
In December 1939, on the request of [[Hans Frank]] in Berlin, the ''Ostbahndirektion'' was given financial independence after paying back 10 million Reichsmarks to DRB.<ref name="Mierzejewski">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/?id=gY_o6_7TP98C&lpg=PA79&dq=Ostbahn%201939%20Cracow&pg=PA79#v=onepage&q=Ostbahn%201939%20Cracow&f=false |title=Most Valuable Asset of the Reich: A History of the German National Railway 1933-1945 |publisher=Univ. of North Carolina Press |work=Volume 2 |date=Jun 19, 2003 |accessdate=9 February 2014 |author=Alfred C. Mierzejewski |pages=78–80|isbn=9780807825747 }}</ref> The removal of all bomb damage was completed in 1940.<ref name="Pottgiesser">{{cite book |url=http://www.zvab.com/displayBookDetails.do?itemId=225830333&b=1 |title=Die Deutsche Reichsbahn im Ostfeldzug 1939 - 1944 |publisher=Kurt Vowinkel Verlag |author=Hans Pottgiesser |orig-year=1960 |year=1975 |pages=17–18 |quote=[http://forum.axishistory.com/viewtopic.php?f=66&p=1844320#p1844320 Excerpts.]}}</ref> The Polish management was either executed in mass shooting actions (see: the 1939 ''[[Intelligenzaktion]]'' and the 1940 [[German AB-Aktion in Poland]]) or imprisoned at the [[Nazi concentration camps]].{{r|Masłowska}} Managerial jobs were staffed with German officials in a wave of some 8,000 instant promotions.<ref name="Wasilewski"/> The new Eastern Division of DRB acquired {{convert|7,192|km}} of new railway lines and 1,052 km of (mostly industrial) narrow gauge in [[Polish areas annexed by Nazi Germany|the annexed areas]].{{r|Masłowska}}
The first Polish agglomeration [[Expulsion of Poles by Nazi Germany|subjected to forcible expulsion of Polish nationals]] was the port city of [[Gdynia]]. In total, 70,000-80,000 civilians had been expelled.<ref name="pap">{{cite web |trans-title=W Gdyni odsłonięto pomnik wysiedlonych przez niemieckich okupantów |title=Monument unveiled in Gdynia to victims of Nazi German expulsions |publisher=Dzieje.pl |url=http://dzieje.pl/aktualnosci/w-gdyni-odslonieto-pomnik-wysiedlonych-przez-niemieckich-okupantow |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160203101932/http://dzieje.pl/aktualnosci/w-gdyni-odslonieto-pomnik-wysiedlonych-przez-niemieckich-okupantow |url-status=dead |archive-date=3 February 2016 |date=14 October 2014 |author=[[Polish Press Agency|PAP]]}}</ref> The forced displacement of 18,000–20,000 [[Silesian Voivodeship (1920–39)|Poles from Silesia]] began during [[Action Saybusch]] of 1939 and ballooned to around 265,000 before 1944, on top of 630,000 expelees from the [[Wartheland]].{{r|TPiotr22}}<ref name="tygodnik">{{cite web|url=http://tygodnik.onet.pl/1,41565,druk.html |title=Mama wzięła ino chleb |trans-title=Mom took only the bread |publisher=[[Tygodnik Powszechny]] |work=Historia |date=16 February 2010 |accessdate=31 January 2016 |author=Anna Machcewicz |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120318131952/http://tygodnik.onet.pl/1%2C41565%2Cdruk.html |archivedate=18 March 2012 }}</ref> The [[Expulsion of Poles by Nazi Germany#Expulsions from Polish territories annexed by Nazi Germany|total number of Polish nationals deported]] from [[Polish areas annexed by Nazi Germany]] reached 923,000.<ref name="TPiotr22">{{cite book |title=Poland's Holocaust: Ethnic Strife, Collaboration with Occupying Forces and Genocide in the Second Republic, 1918-1947 |author-link=Tadeusz Piotrowski (sociologist) |first=Tadeusz |last=Piotrowski |publisher=McFarland |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hC0-dk7vpM8C&q=packing+923%2C000 |year=1998 |isbn=978-0786403714|page=22}}</ref> The DRB trains were used to [[ethnic cleansing|cleanse and resettle]] interwar Poland with the German-speaking colonists in the name of "[[Lebensraum]]".<ref>Berghahn, Volker R. (1999). [https://books.google.com/books?id=j6VCNno2DVMC&lpg=PA15&vq=Volker%2BR.%2BBerghahn%2B1999&pg=PA15#v=snippet&q=Volker+R.+Berghahn+1999&f=false "Germans and Poles 1871–1945".] in ''Germany and Eastern Europe: Cultural Identities and Cultural Differences'' (Rodopi), pp. 15-34; {{ISBN|9042006889}}.</ref>
[[File:Pruszkow Transit Camp transport departure.jpg|thumb|260px|Expulsion of civilians from Poland's capital after the [[Warsaw Uprising]], through ''[[Durchgangslager|Dulag]]'' in [[Pruszków]]. Female prisoners attended by Red Cross. Prisoners were sent to concentration camps including [[Auschwitz]].<ref>{{cite web |title=The unloading ramps and selections |publisher=Auschwitz-Birkenau State Museum |url=http://auschwitz.org/en/history/auschwitz-and-shoah/the-unloading-ramps-and-selections |quote=Transports of Poles from Warsaw during the Uprising there, sent to Auschwitz by way of the transit camp in Pruszków, were unloaded at the third ramp built in 1943 inside Birkenau.}}</ref>]]
{{further|War crimes in occupied Poland during World War II}} The German SS employed ''Ostbahn'' to conduct the [[first mass transport to Auschwitz concentration camp]] (which just opened) in mid June 1940.<ref name="csro">{{cite web |title=Pierwszy Transport do KL Auschwitz: 14 Czerwca 1940 |trans-title=The First Transport |work=Narodowy Dzień Pamięci Ofiar Nazistowskich Obozów Koncentracyjnych |at=Państwowe Muzeum Auschwitz - Birkenau |publisher=Chrześcijańskie Stowarzyszenie Rodzin Oświęcimskich |year=2010 |author=CSRO |url=http://www.chsro.pl/pierwszy-transport/lista.html}}</ref> Notably, the Birkenau infamous "Gate of Death" for the incoming freight trains at Auschwitz was built in 1943 long after its gas chambers went into operation.<ref name="AR">{{cite book |title=Auschwitz: The Nazi Solution |author=Andrew Rawson |publisher=Pen and Sword |year=2015 |isbn=978-1473855410 |page=29 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=izigBwAAQBAJ&lpg=PA29&vq=%22Gate%2Bof%2BDeath%22&pg=PA29#v=snippet&q=%22Gate+of+Death%22&f=false}}</ref> Expulsions were part of a broader Nazi policy called ''[[Generalplan Ost]]''.<ref name=Gellately>{{cite book |first=Robert |last=Gellately |quote=Reviewed works: ''Vom Generalplan Ost zum Generalsiedlungsplan'' by [[Czesław Madajczyk]]. ''Der "Generalplan Ost". Hauptlinien der nationalsozialistischen Planungs- und Vernichtungspolitik'' by Mechtild Rössler; Sabine Schleiermacher. Central European History, Vol. 29, No. 2 (1996), pp. 270–274. |title=The Specter of Genocide |isbn=978-0521527507 |year=2003 |pages=254–257 |url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=k9Ro7b0tWz4C&q=blueprints+revisions+Madajczyk |author-link=Robert Gellately}}</ref><ref name=Madajczyk>{{cite book |quote=Madajczyk, Czesław. "Die Besatzungssysteme der Achsenmächte. Versuch einer komparatistischen Analyse". ''Studia Historiae Oeconomicae'' vol. 14 (1980): pp. 105-122 [1]. |title-link=Hitler's War in the East 1941−1945 |title=Hitler's War in the East, 1941–1945: A Critical Assessment |author-link1=Gerd R. Ueberschär |author-link2=Rolf-Dieter Müller |first1=Gerd R. |last1=Ueberschär |first2=Rolf-Dieter |last2=Müller |chapter=The War of Annihilation |chapter-url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=IfHaDYVfGlgC&q=Madajczyk+Germanic+occupiers |pages=220, 289 |isbn=978-1571812933 |publisher=Berghahn |year=2002}}</ref> The plan resulted in forced removal of over 1.7 million ethnic Poles from their homes.<ref name="G/L">{{cite book |authors=Janusz Gumkowski & Kazimierz Leszczynski |title=Hitler's War; Hitler's Plans for Eastern Europe |year=1961 |work=Selections from Poland under Nazi Occupation |publisher=Polonia Publishing House |location=Warsaw |pages=7–33, 164–178 |url=http://www.atsweb.neu.edu/holocaust/Hitlers_Plans.htm|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120413024247/http://www.atsweb.neu.edu/holocaust/Hitlers_Plans.htm |url-status=dead |archive-date=2012-04-13 |via=Internet Archive from Northeastern University Holocaust Awareness Committee}}</ref> Poles were deported to any one of the German [[Forced labour under German rule during World War II|forced labour camps]] including over 30 ''[[Polenlager]]'' camps in Germany and in German-occupied territory.<ref name="Davies338">{{cite book |author=Norman Davies |year=1982 |title=Polenlagers |work=God's Playground, a History of Poland: 1795 to the present |publisher=Columbia University Press |page=338 |isbn=978-0199253401 |accessdate=2 February 2016 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9Tbed6iMNLEC&q=Polenlager#v=snippet&q=Polenlager&f=false}}</ref>
Mass deportations of Polish nationals using freight trains (but also [[Lorry|lorries]]) took place during the [[Ethnic cleansing of Zamojszczyzna by Nazi Germany|ethnic cleansing of Zamojszczyzna]] between November 1942 and July 1943, in which all [[Ordnungspolizei#Police Battalions|branches of German police]] including Orpo and ''[[Sonderdienst]]'', as well as Wehrmacht and the [[Ukrainian Auxiliary Police]] participated.<ref name="Jaczyńska">{{cite book | url=http://ipn.gov.pl/__data/assets/pdf_file/0007/83266/1-40750.pdf | title=Aktion Zamosc | publisher=[[Institute of National Remembrance]] | work=Pamięć.pl Nr 8/2012 | location=OBEP IPN, Lublin | date=2012 | accessdate=2 February 2016 | author=Agnieszka Jaczyńska | at=30-35 (1-5 in PDF) | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150528142101/http://ipn.gov.pl/__data/assets/pdf_file/0007/83266/1-40750.pdf | archive-date=28 May 2015 | url-status=dead | df=dmy-all }}</ref> Over 110,000 Poles were forcibly removed from liquidated villages in the General Government, including around 30,000 children most of whom were never found.<ref name="prawy">{{cite web |title=Niemieckie wysiedlenia Polaków z Zamojszczyzny. Zabili 10 tys. dzieci |trans-title=German deportations of Poles from the Zamość region. Ten thousand children killed |author=Paweł Brojek |publisher=Prawy.pl - Portal poświęcony Polsce, rodzinie i tradycji |url=http://www.prawy.pl/wesprzyj-nas/77-historia/2132-niemieckie-wysiedlenia-polakow-z-zamojszczyzny-zabili-10-tys-dzieci |year=2014 }}{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> In the second phase of the same plan which was dubbed the ''Ukraineraktion'', the Germans brought in trainloads of Ukrainian peasants into the area of [[Zamość]],<!--Kreis Zamosc: [[Ethnic cleansing of Zamojszczyzna by Nazi Germany]]--> in order to form a buffer zone shielding the 10,000 ethic German colonists arriving ''[[Heim ins Reich]]'' from Romania among other places. By the end of March 1943, over 7,000 Ukrainian peasants were placed in the areas surrounding the settlers, and 116 villages around Zamość had been cleansed of their Polish inhabitants.<ref>[[Czesław Madajczyk]] (1979), ''[https://books.google.ca/books?id=PD1KAAAAIAAJ&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=Umsiedler Zamojszczyzna – Sonderlaboratorium SS.]'' Vol. 1–2. Warsaw: LSW.</ref><ref name="ipn40">{{cite journal |journal=Biuletyn IPN Nr 40 (5) / 2004 |issn=1641-9561 |title=Polacy wypędzeni |author=[[Grzegorz Motyka]] |at=pp. 4-26 / 104 in PDF |url=https://ipn.gov.pl/download/1/18038/1-3930.pdf}}</ref><!--[[Zamość Uprising]]-->
[[File:WWII Krakow - 04.jpg|thumb|left|One of the 1942 executions of the Polish railwaymen kept hanging for two days along the tracks in [[Kraków]], for their alleged sabotage action in [[Bieżanów]]<ref name="Brodacki">{{cite web |url=http://www.naszawitryna.pl/jedwabne_200.html |title=Co z tymi napisami? |publisher=Nasza Witryna, reprint from Tygodnik Solidarność |work=W 1942 roku w Krakowie |date=2001-06-25 |accessdate=8 February 2014 |author=Krystian Brodacki |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110914125851/http://www.naszawitryna.pl/jedwabne_200.html |archivedate=14 September 2011 }}</ref>]]
{{further|Forced labour under German rule during World War II}} The ''Deutsche Reichsbahn'' acquired new infrastructure in Poland worth in excess of 8,278,600,000 [[Polish złoty|złoty]],<ref name="Bujniewicz">{{cite web |url=http://tetragon.com.pl/publikacje/CAW_Kolejnictwo_wprowadzenie.pdf |title=Możliwości finansowe PKP w przebudowie i rozbudowie kolejnictwa |publisher=Wydawnictwo Tetragon Publishing |work=Kolejnictwo w przygotowaniach obronnych Polski w latach 1935–1939 |year=2009 |accessdate=8 February 2014 |author=Ireneusz Bujniewicz |page=22 |via=PDF file, direct download 363 KB |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222043616/http://tetragon.com.pl/publikacje/CAW_Kolejnictwo_wprowadzenie.pdf |archive-date=22 February 2014 |url-status=dead }}</ref> including some of the largest locomotive factories in Europe, the [[H. Cegielski – Poznań]] renamed DWM, and [[Fablok]] in [[Chrzanów]] renamed ''Oberschlesische Lokomotivwerke'' Krenau producing engines Ty37 and Pt31 (designed in Poland), as well as the locomotive parts factory Babcock-Zieleniewski in [[Sosnowiec]] renamed Ferrum AG (tasked with making parts to [[V-1 flying bomb|V-1]] i [[V-2 rocket]]s also).<ref name="Sosnowiec">{{cite book |url=http://www.nowezaglebie.pl/katalog.net.pdf |title=Sosnowiec |publisher=Zagłębiowska Oficyna Wydawnicza Publishing |work=Katalog Zabytków Techniki Przemysłowej Zagłębia Dąbrowskiego |year=2012 |accessdate=9 February 2014 |author1=Michał Kubara |author2=Beata Mamcarczyk |author3=Marcin Paździora |author4=Sandra Schab |pages=84–85 |isbn=978-83-928381-1-1 |via=direct download 9.97 MB |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131206163838/http://www.nowezaglebie.pl/katalog.net.pdf |archivedate=6 December 2013 }}</ref> Under the new management, formerly Polish companies began producing German engines BR44, BR50 and BR86 as early as 1940 virtually for free, using [[Forced labour under German rule during World War II|forced labor]]. All Polish railwaymen were ordered to return to their place of work, or face death. Beating with fists became commonplace, although perceived as shocking by Polish {{nobreak|long-term}} professionals. Their public executions were introduced in 1942.<ref name="Masłowska">{{cite journal |first=Teresa |last=Masłowska |url=http://www.pkp.pl/files/09-14.pdf |title=Wojenne Drogi Polskich Kolejarzy |trans-title=On the war paths of Polish railwaymen |journal=Czy Wiesz, że... |date=2 September 2007 |accessdate=8 February 2014 |page=13 |via=PDF file, direct download (644 KB), archived by Wayback Machine. Magazine ''Kurier PKP'' was last published in 2010 |url-status=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120224030523/http://www.pkp.pl/files/09-14.pdf |archivedate=24 February 2012 }}</ref> By 1944, the factories in Poznań and Chrzanów were mass-producing the redesigned "Kriegslok" [[DRB Class 52|BR52]] locomotives for the Eastern front, all stripped of coloured metals by the rule with intentionally shortened lifespan.<ref name="Wasilewski"/> [[File:Train from Warsaw Ghetto at Treblinka August 1942.jpg|thumb|right|Corpses of Jews from the [[Warsaw Ghetto]] who died inside sealed boxcars before reaching [[Treblinka extermination camp]], August 1942]]
Before the onset of [[Operation Reinhard]] which marked the most deadly phase of [[the Holocaust in Poland]] many Jews were transported by road to killing sites such as the [[Chełmno extermination camp]], equipped with [[Nazi gas van|gas van]]s. In 1942, stationary gas chambers were built at Treblinka, Belzec, Sobibor, Majdanek and Auschwitz. After the Nazi takeover of PKP, the train movements, originating inside and outside [[Occupation of Poland (1939–1945)|occupied Poland]] and terminating at death camps, were tracked by [[Dehomag]] using [[IBM]]-supplied card-reading machines and traditional [[waybill]]s produced by the ''Reichsbahn''.<ref name=autogenerated13 /> The Holocaust trains were always managed and directed by native German ''SS'' men posted with that express' role throughout the system.<ref name="Kopówka">{{Citation|author=Edward Kopówka |title=Treblinka II (Monograph, chapt. 3) |language=Polish |url=http://echomatkibozejniepokalaniepoczetej.com/embnp/pages/assets/files/2011-09/dam_ime_na_wieki.pdf |publisher=Drohiczyńskie Towarzystwo Naukowe [The [[Drohiczyn]] Scientific Society] |work=Dam im imię na wieki [I will give them an everlasting name. Isaiah 56:5] |year=2011 |accessdate=9 February 2014 |isbn=978-83-7257-496-1 |via=direct download 20.2 MB |page=97 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141010231757/http://echomatkibozejniepokalaniepoczetej.com/embnp/pages/assets/files/2011-09/dam_ime_na_wieki.pdf |archivedate=10 October 2014 }}</ref>
{{further|Final Solution|German camps in occupied Poland during World War II}} The shipments to camps under Operation Reinhard came mainly from the ghettos. The [[Warsaw Ghetto]] created by Nazi Germans on 16 November 1940 held eventually over 450,000 Jews cramped in an area meant for about 60,000 people. The second-largest [[Łódź Ghetto|Ghetto in Łódź]] held 204,000 Jews. Both ghettos had collection points known as ''[[Umschlagplatz]]'' along the rail tracks, with most deportations from Warsaw to Treblinka taking place between 22 July through to 12 September 1942.<ref name="YV">{{cite web |url=http://www1.yadvashem.org/odot_pdf/microsoft%20word%20-%205724.pdf |title=Aktion Reinhard |publisher=Yad Vashem Shoah Resource Center, The International School for Holocaust Studies. |quote=''See:'' 'Aktion Reinhard' named after [[Reinhard Heydrich]], the main organizer of the "[[Final Solution]]"; also, [[Treblinka]], 50 miles northeast of [[Warsaw]], set up June/July 1942.}}</ref><ref name="Shapiro">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/?id=dnMMxHaUzT8C&pg=PA35&dq=%22Gross+Aktion+of+July+to+September%22 |title=Holocaust Chronicles |publisher=Published by KTAV Publishing Inc. 1999, 302 pages. |accessdate=5 February 2014 |author=Robert Moses Shapiro |quote=... the so-called Gross Aktion of July to September 1942... 300,000 Jews murdered by bullet of gas (page 35).|isbn=9780881256307 |year=1999 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://blogcritics.org/archives/2006/04/26/062553.php |title=Holocaust Remembrance Day in Warsaw |accessdate=5 February 2014 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090426013945/http://blogcritics.org/archives/2006/04/26/062553.php |archivedate=26 April 2009 }}</ref> The gassing at Treblinka started on 23 July 1942, with two pendulum trains delivering victims six days each week ranging from about 4,000 to 7,000 victims per transport, the first in the early morning and the second in the mid-afternoon.<ref name="Kopówka2">{{Citation|ref=harv |last1=Kopówka |first1=Edward |author-link1=Edward Kopówka |last2=Rytel-Andrianik |first2=Paweł |title=Treblinka II – Obóz zagłady (Treblinka II Death Camp) |url=http://echomatkibozejniepokalaniepoczetej.com/embnp/pages/assets/files/2011-09/dam_ime_na_wieki.pdf |publisher=Drohiczyńskie Towarzystwo Naukowe |work=Monograph, chapt. 3: ibidem |isbn=978-83-7257-496-1 |via=[[Drohiczyn]] Scientific Society, direct download 20.2 MB. |page=94 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141010231757/http://echomatkibozejniepokalaniepoczetej.com/embnp/pages/assets/files/2011-09/dam_ime_na_wieki.pdf |archivedate=2014-10-10 }}</ref> All new arrivals were sent immediately to the undressing area by the ''Sonderkommando'' squad that managed the arrival platform, and from there to the gas chambers. According to German records, including the [[Stroop Report|official report]] by ''SS'' ''[[Brigadeführer]]'' [[Jürgen Stroop]], some 265,000 Jews were transported in [[freight train]]s from the Warsaw Ghetto to Treblinka during this period. The murder operation code-named [[Grossaktion Warsaw (1942)|Grossaktion Warsaw]] concluded several months before the subsequent [[Warsaw Ghetto Uprising]] resulting in new deportations.<ref name="ushmm-uprising">{{cite web |url=http://www.ushmm.org/wlc/en/article.php?ModuleId=10005188 |title=Warsaw Ghetto Uprising |publisher=US Holocaust Memorial Museum |date=10 June 2013 |accessdate=25 August 2013 |author=Holocaust Encyclopedia |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120502213631/http://www.ushmm.org/wlc/en/article.php?ModuleId=10005188 |archivedate=2 May 2012 }}</ref> The Nazi [[Höfle Telegram|1942 record]] of the total number of victims most of whom were transported by train to Operation Reinhard death camps, including cumulative numbers known today, is as follows: {| width="100%" |width="62%" valign="top"| {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:85%" |- ! Location ! Numbers and notes |- | [[Belzec]]{{space|3}} | quoted: 434,508 (real total of '''600,000''' with 246,922 deportees from within the semi-colonial [[General Government]] alone, per contemporary research) <ref name="Małczyński-42">{{cite journal | url=https://www.academia.edu/2626602 | title=Drzewa "żywe pomniki" w Muzeum – Miejscu Pamięci w Bełżcu [Trees as living monuments at Bełżec] | journal=Współczesna Przeszłość, 125-140, Poznań 2009 | date=2009-01-19 | accessdate=8 August 2013 | author=Jacek Małczyński | pages=39–46}}</ref> |- | [[Majdanek]]{{space|3}} | quoted: 24,733 (cumulative number of '''130,000''' victims, per [[Majdanek State Museum]] research) <ref name="Reszka">{{cite web|url=http://en.auschwitz.org.pl/m/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=44&Itemid=8 |title=Majdanek Victims Enumerated. Changes in the history textbooks? |accessdate=April 29, 2013 |author=Paweł Reszka |date=Dec 23, 2005 |work=Gazeta Wyborcza |publisher=Auschwitz-Birkenau State Museum |format=Internet Archive |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111106112513/http://en.auschwitz.org.pl/m/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=44&Itemid=8 |archivedate=November 6, 2011 }}</ref> |- | [[Sobibor]]{{space|3}} | quoted: 101,370 (final count in excess of '''200,000''' with 140,000 from [[Lublin]], and 25,000 Jews from [[Lviv]] alone per contemporary historians) <ref>[[Raul Hilberg]] (1985), ''[[The Destruction of the European Jews]]'' by Yale University Press, p. 1219. {{ISBN|978-0-300-09557-9}}, versus [[Thomas Blatt]] (1983), ''[http://www.sobibor.info/index.html Sobibor - The Forgotten Revolt]'' by H.E.P., pp. 3, 92; {{ISBN|0964944200}}</ref> |- | [[Treblinka]]{{space|3}} | quoted: 713,555 (overall minimum of '''800,000'''–'''900,000''' at Camp II and '''20,000''' at Camp I) <ref>Holocaust Encyclopedia, [https://web.archive.org/web/20120503084809/http://www.ushmm.org/wlc/en/article.php?ModuleId=10005193 "Treblinka"] United States Holocaust Memorial Museum.</ref> |} |[[File:Hoefletelegram.jpg|right|thumb|270px|The [[Höfle Telegram]] lists the number of arrivals to the Aktion Reinhard Camps through 1942 (1,274,166)]] |} [[File:Birkenau wagon kolejowy2019.jpg|right|thumb|A railway car used for deportations to Auchwitz-Birkenau displayed in Auschwitz II (Birkenau) camp.]] [[File:Holocaust trains Auschwitz-Birkenau Museum exhibition.jpg|right|thumb|Part of the exhibition at the Museum in the former Auschwitz I camp dedicated to the deportations to the Auschwitz-Birkenau camp.]] The [[Höfle Telegram]] lists the number of arrivals to the Reinhard camps through 1942 as 1,274,166 Jews based on ''Reichsbahn'' own records. The last train to be sent to [[Treblinka extermination camp]] left [[Białystok Ghetto]] on 18 August 1943; all prisoners were murdered in gas chambers after which the camp closed down per [[Odilo Globocnik|Globocnik]]'s directive.<ref name=autogenerated4 /> Of the more than 245,000 Jews who passed through the [[Łódź Ghetto]],<ref name="Rosenberg">{{cite encyclopedia |url=https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/Holocaust/lodz.html |title=The Lódz Ghetto: History & Overview (1939 - 1945) |encyclopedia=Jewish Virtual Library |year=1998 |accessdate=8 February 2014 |author=Jennifer Rosenberg}}</ref> the last 68,000 inmates, by then the largest final gathering of Jews in all of [[German occupied Europe]], had been liquidated by the Nazis after 7 August 1944. They were told to prepare for resettlement; instead, over the next 23 days they were sent to [[Auschwitz concentration camp|Birkenau]] by train at the rate of 2,500 per day, with some of the crippled selected by [[Josef Mengele]] for his "medical experiments".<ref name=autogenerated3 />
The rail traffic on most Polish railway lines was extremely dense. In 1941, an average of 420 German trains were passing through every 24 hours on top of Polish internal traffic; in 1944 the number rose to 506 military transports per day.{{r|Masłowska}} No new lines had been built by Nazi Germany. Most supplies from layover yards were taken away. However, almost all Polish language signs were replaced with German, which led to new problems. On 24 November 1944, two trains (one German with military [[cargo]], and one Polish) traveling at regular speeds collided head-on in [[Barwałd Średni]] near [[Wadowice]]. It was the biggest train collision of World War II in occupied Poland with both locomotives and nearly half of their trainsets destroyed completely. Some 130 people from the Polish passenger train were killed and over 100 wounded.<ref name="Wolna Droga">{{cite web |url=http://www.wolnadroga.pl/index.php?s=7&n=312059 |title=Barwałd: W rocznicę tragicznych wydarzeń |publisher=Portal dwutygodnika Wolna Droga - Pismo Sekcji Krajowej Kolejarzy |work=Archiwum: W rocznicę tragicznych wydarzeń | accessdate=10 February 2014 |author=Adam Dyląg}}</ref><ref name="polskierekordy">{{cite web |url=http://polskierekordy.pl/web/rekord/najwieksze-katastrofy-kolejowe |title=1944-11-24, Barwałd Średni (śląskie) |publisher=Towarzystwo Kontroli Rekordów Niecodziennych |work=Największe katastrofy kolejowe |date=2011-10-20 |accessdate=8 February 2014 |author=J. Studnicki|display-authors=etal}}</ref> {{clear}}
===Romania=== [[File:פוגרום יאשי 5.jpg|thumb|right|Pulling dead Jews from the [[Iași pogrom#Pogrom and death train|Holocaust train in Romania]] traveling for 7 days in total, July 1941.<ref name="Wiesel_Commission"/>]] {{See also|Responsibility for the Holocaust#Romania}} [[Căile Ferate Române]] (Romanian Railways) were involved in the transport of Jewish and Romani people to concentration camps in [[Romanian Old Kingdom]], [[Bessarabia]], northern [[Bukovina]], and [[Transnistria Governorate|Transnistria (Romania)]].<ref name="Wiesel_Commission">{{citation |title=Report of the International Commission on the Holocaust in Romania |url=https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/Holocaust/romaniareport.html |id=''Final Report'' (consisting of 19 PDF files) |date=November 11, 2004 |publisher=Yad Vashem |accessdate=2017-09-29 |at=pp.20–22 of Ch.5 |chapter=The Iasi Death Trains. ''Holocaust in Romania'' (Chapter 5) |location=Bucharest |chapter-url=https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/Holocaust/Romania/five.pdf }}</ref> In a notable example, after the [[Iasi pogrom]] events, Jews were forcibly loaded onto freight cars with planks hammered in place over the windows and traveled for seven (7) days in unimaginable conditions.<ref name="Wiesel_Commission"/> Many died and were gravely affected by lack of air, blistering heat, lack of water, food or medical attention. These veritable ''death trains'' arrived to their destinations [[Podu Iloaiei]] and [[Călăraşi]] with only one-fifth of their passengers alive.<ref name="Wiesel_Commission"/><ref name="Rozen">{{cite web |url=http://www.survivors-romania.org/text_doc/the_holocaust_under_the_antonescu_government.htm |title=The Holocaust under the Antonescu government |author=Marcu Rozen |year=2006 |publisher=Association of Romanian Jews Victims of the Holocaust (A.R.J.V.H.) |accessdate=2014-02-27 }}</ref><ref name="Podu Iloaiei">{{cite web |title=Holocaust in Podu Iloaiei, Romania |url=http://isurvived.org/2Postings/holocaust-Podul_Iloaiei-RO.html}}</ref> No official apology was released yet by [[Căile Ferate Române]] for their role in the Holocaust in Romania.
===Slovakia=== {{main|List of Holocaust transports from Slovakia}} On 9 September 1941, the parliament of the [[Slovak State]] ratified the Jewish Codex, a series of laws and regulations that stripped Slovakia's 89,000 Jews of their civil rights and means of economic survival. The ruling [[Slovak People’s Party]] paid 500 Reichsmarks per expelled Jew, in exchange for a promise that the deportees would never return to Slovakia. Except for Croatia, Slovakia was the only Axis ally to pay for the deportation of its own Jewish population. Most of the Jewish population perished in two waves of deportations. The first, in 1942, took away two-thirds of the Slovak Jews; the second wave after the [[Slovak National Uprising]] in 1944 claimed another 13,500 victims, 10,000 of whom did not return.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia |last1=Rajcan |first1=Vanda |last2=Vadkerty |first2=Madeline |first3=Ján |last3=Hlavinka |entry=Slovakia|editor1-last=Megargee|editor1-first=Geoffrey P. |editorlink=Geoffrey P. Megargee |editor2-last=White|editor2-first=Joseph R.|editor3-last=Hecker|editor3-first=Mel |series=Encyclopedia of Camps and Ghettos |volume=3 |title=Camps and Ghettos under European Regimes Aligned with Nazi Germany|location=Bloomington |isbn=978-0-253-02373-5 |publisher=[[United States Holocaust Memorial Museum]] |ref=harv |date=2018|pp=842–852}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Nižňanský |first1=Eduard |title=The discussions of Nazi Germany on the deportation of Jews in 1942 – the examples of Slovakia, Rumania and Hungary |url=http://www.historickycasopis.sk/pdf/HCsupplement2011.pdf|journal=Historický časopis |date=2011 |volume=59 |issue=Supplement |page=121 |ref=harv |issn=0018-2575}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Kamenec |first1=Ivan|translator1-last=Styan |translator1-first=Martin |title=On the Trail of Tragedy: The Holocaust in Slovakia |date=2007 |publisher=Hajko & Hajková |location=Bratislava |isbn=978-80-88700-68-5 |ref=harv |language=en|orig-year=1991|p=337}} </ref>
===Switzerland=== Switzerland was not invaded because its mountain bridges and tunnels between Germany and Italy were too vital for them to go into war.<ref name="M.G. Jud-1">Markus G. Jud, [http://history-switzerland.geschichte-schweiz.ch/switzerland-second-world-war-ii.html Switzerland's Role in World War II] at ''History of Switzerland''.</ref> Also, the Swiss banks provided necessary access to international markets by dealing in pilfered gold.<ref>Markus G. Jud, [http://history-switzerland.geschichte-schweiz.ch/holocaust-looted-jewish-assets.html Looted Assets, Gold Transactions and Dormant Accounts] at ''Switzerland during World War II''.</ref> There were 18,000 Jews living in Switzerland at the onset of World War II.<ref name="Switzerland-YV">[http://www.yadvashem.org/odot_pdf/Microsoft%20Word%20-%206062.pdf Switzerland] at [[Yad Vashem]] International School for Holocaust Studies.</ref> The country did not turn over their own Jews to the Germans, but according to three anonymous eyewitnesses, allowed the Holocaust trains (aware of them since 1942) to use the [[Gotthard Tunnel]] on the way to the camps.<ref>{{cite news |last=Marks|first=David|title=The Train {{!}} Switzerland |url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/shows/nazis/train/ |accessdate=17 December 2019 |work=[[Frontline (American TV program)|Frontline]] |publisher=[[PBS]]}}</ref> Most war supplies to Italy were shipped through the Austrian [[Brenner Pass]].<ref>[http://www.yale.edu/lawweb/avalon/imt/partxii.htm The Avalon Project: The Versailles Treaty June 28, 1919] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070208171110/http://www.yale.edu/lawweb/avalon/imt/partxii.htm |date=February 8, 2007 }} at www.Yale.edu</ref> [[File:Gotthard Tunnel 05.jpg|thumb|250px|Entrance to the [[Gotthard Tunnel]] ]]
There exists substantial evidence that these shipments included Italian forced labour workers and trainloads of Jews in 1944 during the Nazi occupation of northern Italy,<ref name="Marks">David Marks, [https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/shows/nazis/train/ The Train], BBC Frontline</ref> when a German train passed through Switzerland every 10 minutes. The need for the tunnel was complicated by the British [[Royal Air Force]] having bombed and disrupted services through the Brenner Pass, as well as a heavy snowfall in the winter of 1944–45.<ref name=autogenerated12 />
Of 43 trains that could be tracked down by the 1996 [[Bergier Commission]], 39 went via Austria (Brenner, [[Tarvisio]]), one via France ([[Ventimiglia, Italy|Ventimiglia]]-[[Nice]]). The commission could not find any evidence that the other three passed through Switzerland. It is possible that the train could have been carrying [[dissident]]s back from concentration camps. Started in 1944, some repatriation trains went through Switzerland officially, organised by the [[International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement|Red Cross]].<ref name="M.G. Jud-1"/><ref>''[http://www.uek.ch/en/index.htm Independent Commission of Experts, Switzerland—World War II''.] Bergier Commission for the Swiss Government</ref>
==Aftermath== After the Soviet Army began making severe inroads into [[German-occupied Europe]] and the Allies landed in [[Normandy]] in June 1944, the number of trains and transported persons began to vary greatly. By November 1944, with the closure of Birkenau and the advance of the Soviet Army, the death trains had ceased. Conversely, the subsequent [[Death marches (Holocaust)|death marches]] had the advantage of being able to utilize the forced labour to build defences.
As the Soviet and Allied Armies made their final pushes, the Nazis transported some of the concentration camp survivors either to other camps located inside the collapsing Third Reich, or to the border areas where they believed they could negotiate the release of captured Nazi [[Prisoners of War]] in return for the "Exchange Jews" or those that were born outside the Nazi occupied territories. Many of the inmates were transported via the infamous death marches, but among other transports three trains left Bergen-Belsen in April 1945 bound for [[Theresienstadt concentration camp|Theresienstadt]]—all were liberated.<ref name=autogenerated7 />
The last recorded train is the one used to transport the women of the [[Flossenbürg concentration camp|Flossenbürg March]], where for three days in March 1945 the remaining survivors were crammed into cattle cars to await further transport. Only 200 of the original 1000 women survived the entire trip to Bergen-Belsen.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/19990203065157/http://www.neveragain.org/1945.htm NAAF Holocaust Project Timeline: 1945.] Never Again.org.</ref>
==Remembrance and commemoration== {{Css Image Crop|Image = ISR-2015-Jerusalem-Yad Vashem-Wagon monument 01.jpg |bSize = 300|cWidth = 220|cHeight = 125|oTop = 45|oLeft = 28|Location = right|Description = The wagon monument, [[Yad Vashem]], Jerusalem.}}
There are numerous national commemorations of the mass transportation of Jews in the "Final Solution" across Europe, as well as some lingering controversies surrounding the history of the railway systems utilized by the Nazis.
===Poland=== [[File:Umschlagplatz noc.JPG|thumb|left|Warsaw national monument to Holocaust trains at the former ''[[Umschlagplatz]]'' of the [[Warsaw Ghetto]]]]
All railway lines leading to death camps built in occupied Poland are ceremonially cut off from the existing railway system in the country, similar to the well-preserved arrival point at Auschwitz known as the "Judenrampe" platform. The commemorative monuments are traditionally erected at collection points elsewhere. In 1988, a national monument was created at the ''[[Umschlagplatz]]'' of the [[Warsaw Ghetto]]. Designed by architect Hanna Szmalenberg and sculptor Władysław Klamerus, it consists of a stone structure symbolizing an open freight car.<ref>Sybille Steinbacher, ''Auschwitz: A History'', trans. by [[Shaun Whiteside]], Penguin Books. {{ISBN|0-14-102142-X}}.</ref> In [[Kraków]], the memorial to Jews from the [[Kraków Ghetto]] deported during the Holocaust spreads over the entire deportation site known as the Square of the Ghetto Heroes (''Plac Bohaterow Getta''). Inaugurated in December 2005, it consists of oversized steel chairs (each representing 1,000 victims), designed by architects Piotr Lewicki and Kazimierz Latak.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jewishkrakow.net/en/see/krakow-ghetto/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724023814/http://www.jewishkrakow.net/en/see/krakow-ghetto/ |url-status=dead |archive-date=24 July 2011 |title=The Krakow Ghetto |publisher=JewishKrakow.net |accessdate=7 February 2014 }}</ref> At the former [[Łódź Ghetto]], the monument was built at the [[Radegast train station]] (''Bahnhof Radegast''), where approximately 200,000 Polish, Austrian, German, Luxemburg and Czech Jews boarded the trains on the way to their deaths in the period from 16 January 1942, to 29 August 1944.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.centrumdialogu.com/en/memorial/radegast-station |title=Memorial Radegast station |publisher=Centrum Dialogu im. Marka Edelmana w Łodzi |year=2013 |accessdate=7 February 2014 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203013353/http://www.centrumdialogu.com/en/memorial/radegast-station |archivedate=3 December 2013 }}</ref><ref name="Dobroszycki">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/?id=d1-U17adWKIC&pg=PA514&lpg=PA514&dq=Radogoszcz+Station#v=onepage&q=Radogoszcz%20Station&f=false |title=The Chronicle of the Lodz Ghetto, 1941-1944 |publisher=Yale University Press |year=1984 |author=[[Lucjan Dobroszycki]] |pages=514–515 |isbn=978-0300039245}}</ref>
===Germany=== [[File:Holocaust memorial tree.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Memorial to the Murdered Jews of Europe]], Berlin]]
In 2004/2005, German historians and journalists began publicly demanding that at the German passenger train stations commemorative exhibits be set up, after the railroad companies in France and the Netherlands began commemorations of Nazi mass deportations in their own train stations.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.nzz.ch/aktuell/startseite/articleD84O6-1.177980 |title=Die Niederländische Bahn und die Judendeportatiopnen |publisher=Neue Zürcher Zeitung |work=Der Centraal Joods Overleg, Amsterdam |date=19 October 2005 |accessdate=4 February 2014 |trans-title=The Dutch Railways and the deportation of Jews}}</ref> The ''[[Deutsche Bahn]]'' AG (DB AG), the state-owned successor of the ''Deutsche Reichsbahn'' replied: "we do not have either the personnel or the financial resources" for that kind of commemoration.<ref>Letter from the Deutsche Bahn AG, 17 December 2004</ref> Demonstrations then began at railway stations in [[Frankfurt am Main]] and in [[Cologne]] as well as inside the long-distance border-crossing trains.<ref>TV 3 sat: Kulturzeit, 10 July 2005</ref> Because the DB AG had responded by having its security personnel repress the protests, German citizens' initiatives rented a historical steam locomotive and installed their own exhibition in remodeled passenger cars. This "Train of Commemoration" made its first journey on the 2007 International Holocaust Remembrance Day of January 27. The ''Deutsche Bahn'' AG refused it access to the main stations in Hamburg and Berlin.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dw.de/holocaust-deportation-exhibit-denied-access-to-berlin-central/a-3252599-1 |title=Holocaust Deportation Exhibit Denied Access to Berlin Central |publisher=Deutsche Welle |date=8 April 2008 |accessdate=4 February 2014 |quote=''Following story:'' "Remembrance train banned from station". The Guardian, 11 April 2008.}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aIgt4DFb4XYI&refer=muse |title=Deutsche Bahn `Embarrasses' Berlin by Hampering Holocaust Show |author=Catherine Hickley |publisher=Bloomberg, Berlin |date=April 8, 2008 }}</ref> German Jewish communities protested against the company levying mileage tariffs and hourly fees for the exhibit (which by December 31, 2013 reached approx. US $290,000).<ref>{{Citation |publisher=SPIEGEL-Online |date=10 March 2008 |url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/germany/row-over-traveling-exhibition-holocaust-survivors-group-slams-german-rail-a-545895.html |title=Row over Traveling Exhibition: Holocaust Survivors' Group Slams German Rail |newspaper=Spiegel Online }}</ref>
Parliamentarians of all parties in the German national parliament called on the DB AG to rethink its behavior.<ref>Zug der Erinnerung, [http://www.zug-der-erinnerung.eu/appelle.html Verkehrsausschuss Deutscher Bundestag], 15 January 2008. {{in lang|de}}</ref> Federal Transport Minister [[Wolfgang Tiefensee]] proposed an exhibition by artist [[Jan Philipp Reemtsma]] on the railways' role in the deportation of 11,000 Jewish children to their deaths in Nazi concentration and extermination camps throughout World War II. Because the CEO of the railroad company maintained his refusal, a "serious rift" occurred between himself and the Minister of Transport.<ref>Spiegel No. 43, 23 October 2006.</ref> On January 23, 2008, a compromise was reached, wherein the DB AG established its own stationary exhibit ''Sonderzüge in den Tod'' [Chartered Trains to Death – Deportation with the German Reichsbahn].<ref name="dw-world">{{cite web|url=http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,2144,3086465,00.html |title=Nazi Death Train Exhibit Opens in Berlin Station |publisher=Deutsche Welle |date=2008-01-24 |accessdate=5 February 2014 |author=DW staff |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080405155023/http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0%2C2144%2C3086465%2C00.html |archivedate=5 April 2008 }}</ref> As national press journals pointed out, the exhibit "contained nearly nothing about the culprits". The post-war careers of those in charge of the railroad remained "totally obscured".<ref>{{Citation |author=Katharina Schuler |publisher= ZEIT-Online |date=24 January 2008 |url=http://www.zeit.de/online/2008/04/bahn-holocaust-ausstellung |title=Sonderzüge in den Tod |language=de |accessdate=7 February 2014 }}</ref> Since 2009 the civil society association ''Train of Commemoration'' which, with its donations financed the exhibition "Train of Commemoration" presented at 130 German stations with 445,000 visitors, has been demanding cumulative compensation for the survivors of these deportations by train. The railroad's proprietors (the German Minister of Transport and the German Minister of Finances) reject this demand.<ref>[http://www.zug-der-erinnerung.eu Zug der Erinnerung] The Train of Memory homepage. {{in lang|de}}</ref>
===France=== [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 101I-027-1476-20A, Marseille, Gare d'Arenc. Deportation von Juden.jpg|thumb|French Jews being loaded into railway trucks in [[Marseilles]], 1943]]
In 1992, [[SNCF]] commissioned a report on its involvement in World War II. The company opened its archives to an independent historian, Christian Bachelier, whose report was released in French in 2000.<ref name="Bankier2011"/><ref name="nytimes2011"/><ref name="DailyMail2010">{{cite news |title=California set to force France's national rail service to reveal its Holocaust role as part of bid for $45m contract |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1291160/French-rail-operator-reveal-Holocaust-role-45bn-Californian-contract-bid.html#ixzz0sZ6U2128 |newspaper=Daily Mail |date=1 July 2010 |accessdate=15 November 2012 |location=London}}</ref> It was translated to English in 2010.<ref name="Shaver"/>
In 2001, a lawsuit was filed against [[Cabinet of France|French government]]-owned rail company SNCF by Georges Lipietz, a [[Holocaust survivor]], who was transported by SNCF to the [[Drancy internment camp]] in 1944.<ref name="BBC2007"/> Lipietz was held at the internment camp for several months before the camp was liberated.<ref name=CBC2006>{{cite news| url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/world/french-railway-must-pay-for-transporting-family-to-nazis-1.575679| title=French railway must pay for transporting family to Nazis| author=CBC News| accessdate=15 November 2012| date=7 June 2006}}</ref> After Lipietz's death the lawsuit was pursued by his family and in 2006 an administrative court in [[Toulouse]] ruled in favor of the Lipietz family. SNCF was ordered to pay 61,000 Euros in restitution. SNCF appealed the ruling at an administrative appeals court in [[Bordeaux]], where in March 2007 the original ruling was overturned.<ref name="BBC2007">{{cite news |title=French railways win WWII appeal |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/6499227.stm |newspaper=BBC |date=27 March 2007 |accessdate=16 November 2012}}</ref><ref name="Reuters2007">{{cite news |title=Court quashes SNCF Nazi deportations ruling |last=Canellas |first=Claude |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2007/03/27/uk-france-holocaust-trial-idUKL2715470420070327 |newspaper=Reuters |date=27 March 2007 |accessdate=15 November 2012}}</ref> According to historian [[Michael Marrus]], the court in Bordeaux "declared the railway company had acted under the authority of the Vichy government and the German occupation" and as such could not be held independently liable.<ref name="Bankier2011">{{cite book |title=Holocaust and Justice |last=Marrus |first=Michael R. |editor1-last=Bankier |editor1-first=David |editor2-last=Michman |editor2-first=Dan |year=2011 |publisher=Berghahn Books |location= |isbn=978-9-65308-353-0 |chapter=Chapter 12: The Case of the French Railways and the Deportation of Jews in 1944 |pages= }}</ref> {{#tag:ref| Following the Lipietz trial, SNCF's involvement in [[World War II]] became the subject of attention in the United States when SNCF explored bids on rail projects in Florida and California, and SNCF's partly owned subsidiary, [[Keolis|Keolis Rail Services America]] bid on projects in Virginia and Maryland.<ref name="Shaver">{{Cite news |last=Shaver |first=Katherine |title=Holocaust group faults VRE contract |work=The Washington Post |accessdate= 15 November 2012 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/07/06/AR2010070605169.html |date=7 July 2010}}</ref> In 2010, Keolis placed a bid on a contract to operate the Brunswick and Camden lines of the [[MARC train]] in Maryland.<ref name="Shaver"/> Following pressure from Holocaust survivors in Maryland, the state passed legislation in 2011 requiring companies bidding on the project to disclose their involvement in the Holocaust.<ref name="Zeitvogel2011">{{cite news |title=US governor signs Holocaust disclosure law |last1=Zeitvogel |first1=Karin |url=http://www.ejpress.org/article/51047 |newspaper=European Jewish Press |date=20 May 2011 |accessdate=16 November 2012 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130414203445/http://www.ejpress.org/article/51047 |archivedate=14 April 2013 }}</ref><ref name="Witte2011">{{cite news |title=Md. governor signs bill on company's WWII role |last1=Witte |first1=Brian |url=http://www.businessweek.com/ap/financialnews/D9NANRI81.htm |newspaper=Businessweek |date=19 May 2011 |accessdate=16 November 2012 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160312084515/http://www.businessweek.com/ap/financialnews/D9NANRI81.htm |archivedate=12 March 2016 }}</ref> Keolis currently operates the [[Virginia Railway Express]], a contract the company received in 2010.<ref name="Shaver"/><ref name="Zeitvogel2011"/> In California, also in 2010, state lawmakers passed the Holocaust Survivor Responsibility Act. The bill, written to require companies to disclose their involvement in World War II,<ref name="Samuel2010">{{cite news |title=SNCF to open war archives to California |last1=Samuel |first1=Henry |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/france/7971894/SNCF-to-open-war-archives-to-California.html |newspaper=The Telegraph |date=30 August 2010 |accessdate=16 November 2012 |location=London}}</ref> was later vetoed by Governor [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]].<ref name="Witte2011"/><ref name="Weikel2010">{{cite news |title=Schwarzenegger vetoes bill requiring rail firms interested in train project to disclose WWII-era activities |last1=Weikel |first1=Dan |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2010/oct/02/local/la-me-holocaust-20101002 |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |date=2 October 2010 |accessdate=16 November 2012}}</ref>
While bidding on these rail contracts, SNCF was criticized for not formally acknowledging and apologizing for its involvement in World War II. In 2011, SNCF chairman [[Guillaume Pepy]] released a formal statement of regrets for the company's actions during World War II.<ref name="nytimes2011">{{Cite news |last=Baume |first=Maïa De La |title=French Railway Formally Apologizes to Holocaust Victims |work=The New York Times |accessdate=26 October 2012 |date=25 January 2011 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/26/world/europe/26france.html }}</ref><ref name="Schofield2010">{{cite news |title=SNCF apologises for role in WWII Jewish deportations |last=Schofield |first=Hugh |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-11751246 |newspaper= |date=13 November 2010 |accessdate=15 November 2012 |work=BBC News}}</ref><ref name="Ganley2010">{{cite news |title=SNCF, French Railroad, Apologizes For Holocaust Role Before Florida Bid |last1=Ganley |first1=Elaine |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/11/14/sncf-railroad-holocaust-apology-_n_783417.html |newspaper=The Huffington Post |date=14 November 2010 |accessdate=16 November 2012}}</ref> Some historians have expressed the opinion that SNCF has been unfairly targeted in the United States for their involvement in World War II. [[Human rights]] attorney Arno Klarsfeld has argued that the negative focus on SNCF was disrespectful to the French railway workers who lost their lives engaging in acts of resistance.<ref name="nytimes2011"/>|group=note}} Marrus wrote in his 2011 essay that the company has nevertheless taken responsibility for their actions and it is the company's willingness to open up their archives revealing involvement in the transportation of Holocaust victims that has led to the recent legal and legislative attention.<ref name="Bankier2011"/>
Between 2002 and 2004 the SNCF helped fund an exhibit on deportation of Jewish children that was organized by Nazi hunter [[Serge and Beate Klarsfeld|Serge Klarsfeld]].<ref name="Bankier2011"/> In 2011, SNCF helped set up a railway station outside of Paris to a [[Shoah Foundation]] for the creation of a memorial to honor Holocaust victims.<ref name="nytimes2011"/> In December 2014, the company came to a $60 million compensation settlement with French Holocaust survivors living in the United States.<ref name="washingtonpost.com"/>
===Netherlands=== [[Nederlandse Spoorwegen]] used its 29 September 2005 apology for its role in the "Final Solution" to launch an equal opportunities and anti-Discrimination policy, in part to be monitored by the Dutch council of Jews.<ref name=autogenerated8>[http://www.expatica.com/actual/article.asp?subchannel_id=19&story_id=23852 Dutch news - Expatica] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071211164905/http://www.expatica.com/actual/article.asp?subchannel_id=19&story_id=23852 |date=2007-12-11 }}</ref>
==Railway companies involved== * [[Deutsche Reichsbahn]], the [[German Reich]] Railway * [[Căile Ferate Române|CFR]], the state railways of Romania * [[Hungarian State Railways|MÁV]], Hungarian State Railways *BDZ (БДЖ), Bulgarian national Railways http://www.bdz.bg/en/ * [[National Railway Company of Belgium]], National Railway Company of Belgium * [[Nederlandse Spoorwegen]] (NS) in the Netherlands <ref name=autogenerated8 /> * [[Ostbahn (General Government)|Ostbahn]], a railway operator set up by the [[General Government]] in occupied Poland<ref>{{Cite book| publisher = Berghahn Books| isbn = 978-0-85745-427-0| last = Gigliotti| first = Simone| title = The Train Journey: Transit, Captivity, and Witnessing in the Holocaust| date = 2009}}</ref> * [[SNCF]], French National Railway Company

revision.text:
[[File:Budapest, Istvántelki Főműhely, vonattemető, 4.jpg|thumb|right|Abandoned trains in Hungary]] A '''train graveyard''' (or '''cemetery''') is where [[train]]s and [[rolling stock]] are discarded while awaiting collection, recycling, or destruction. They might be abandoned and left to decay. The term can also be used to include [[tram]]s. Such [[vehicle graveyard]]s are distinguished from an [[abandoned railway]], which is a [[railway line]] that is no longer used for that purpose, and [[abandoned railway station]]s which are similarly disused. Some train graveyards attract visitors and can be a source of tourism, while others have had a role in preserving the history of the railways.
== Locations == [[File:" Last Train to No-where ".JPG|thumb|Former New York City transit locomotive, abandoned in Alaska]]
Some sites contain numerous trains that have been abandoned. In the United States, just outside [[Watervliet, New York]], there is the main line for the [[Delaware and Hudson Railway]]. Alongside this railway line is a disused stretch of track which is home to rusted locomotives, passenger cars, and freight cars.<ref name="Lomo" /> In [[North Carolina]], a graveyard features trains and trams from across the United States, including a passenger train from Philadelphia and abandoned [[Passenger car (rail)|subway cars]].<ref name="Rumble" /> Istvántelki Főműhely, formerly one of the most important railway repair workshops in Hungary, now lays disused with old rolling stock on site. Many of them were taken there to be repaired before being exhibited in the [[Hungarian Railway History Park]] in [[Budapest]] but never made it.<ref name="AO" /> One particularly sizable site is the [[Woodham Brothers]] scrapyard in [[Barry, Wales]], from which [[List of locomotives saved from Woodham Brothers scrapyard|213 of 297 locomotives]] were rescued by the nascent [[railway preservation]] movement.<ref name="UGM" />. In [[Russia]], there is one in [[Shumkovo]]<ref>[http://www.anews.com.tr/webtv/world/shumkovos-soviet-railway-cemetery Shumkovo's Soviet railway cemetery]</ref>. In Tangshan in north China there are rusting loocmotives on the sidings of now shut-down coal mines. A few have also been moved and exhibited in a Coal Mining Park and Railway museum. <ref>See Youtube slideshow by Chinarail1 in external links below</ref>
Trains can be abandoned in a location because it is deemed too difficult to move them. Two large steam locomotives of the [[Eagle Lake and West Branch Railroad]], for example, were left in a woodland area in the U.S. state of [[Maine]] after the end of a local logging operation because it was not practical to move them from such a remote location.<ref name="Bangor" />
{{wide image|Uyuni Décembre 2007 - Cimetière de Trains 1.jpg|1000px|"Cementerio de Trenes" (train cemetery) in Bolivia}}
Train graveyards can be of interest to [[railfan]]s, [[urban exploration|urban explorers]], and other tourists. The "Cementerio de Trenes" ("train cemetery") near [[Uyuni]], [[Bolivia]], serves as a tourist attraction with trains dating back to the 19th century left to rust in the extensive [[salt pan (geology)|salt flats]] of the [[Salar de Uyuni]].<ref name="Uyuni" /> The site contains a train alleged to have been robbed by [[Butch Cassidy]] and the [[Sundance Kid]] and has been called "one of the most striking and haunting sights in the deserts of southwest Bolivia".<ref name="Teleg10" /><ref name="Expe" />

Due to its rarity, not much is known about this trainset. In the mid 1970s, the [[Romanian Railways]] was looking for an EMU train design that would replace conventional engine-towed local train consists, and also to work for a possible project that would envisage a regional railway network around Bucharest. The project took shape around 1972-1973, being built in 1974. The prototype was derived from the regional passenger cars named "Bonzana" among the travelers, that were made by the IVA factory. The whole trainset was fitted with Minden-Deutz bogies, especially the motor bogies, and the electric equipment was made together by Škoda and Electroputere and it used thyristors. It featured a destination board, open-able from the cab, where a cardboard plaque would be placed showing the route of the train, toilets and curtains. During 10 years of testing the train was heavily modified, mostly of electrical nature. The prototype was rarely used on Bucharest to Brașov duties, but also on [[Bucharest]] to [[Craiova]] or to Călărași trains too. It was withdrawn in the late 1990s. In the old CFR classification it was given the numbers 080-TEA-001/002.{{cite web|url=https://scontent.fotp3-2.fna.fbcdn.net/v/t1.0-9/535026_1286847521341399_6408283076130268535_n.jpg?_nc_cat=0&oh=66b408aed5f7f0f1818ddeebec46c64d&oe=5BD01361|format=JPG|title=Photographic image|website=Scontent.fotp3-2.fna.fbcdn.net|accessdate=6 August 2018}} Series production started in 1984 but only eight of such multiple units were made.{{cite web|url=http://www.railnet.ro/download/file.php?id=149|format=JPG|title=Photographic image|website=Railnet.ro|accessdate=6 August 2018}} These were mostly used by the Cluj regional division for services between Cluj and Teiuș or Dej, but also by the Craiova regional division for trains between Craiova and Motru or Târgu Jiu and by the Bucharest regional division for trains to Călărași. In the new classification they were referred to as the following: *55 00xx, motor driving car, second class, without pantograph *56 00xx, motor cabless car, second class, with pantograph *57 00xx, trailer car, first class, without pantograph *57 00xx, trailer car, second class, without pantograph *56 00xx, motor cabless car, second class, with pantograph *55 00xx, motor driving car, second class, without pantograph Whilst officially they were known as the RES 1870 kW by the [[Electroputere]], where RES stood for "Suburban Electric Multiple Unit" (Ramă Electrică Suburbană). Another prototype was realized in 1991, which had stronger traction motors of 2870 kW overall.{{cite web|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/128377519@N08/16463606020|title=Rama Electrica Suburbana|website=Flickr.com|accessdate=6 August 2018}} But all these units were plagued with brake and electrical equipment issues, so after the 1990s they were quickly retired, in favour of [[CFR Class EA]]-pulled local trains. Nowadays the only remaining example is the 1991 prototype, although a few cars of the series production trainsets were known to have survived years ago. ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Trains]] [[Category:1975 establishments in Romania]] [[Category:1996 disestablishments in Romania]]
