revision.text:
'''Sidorenko's conjecture''' is an important [[conjecture]] in the field of [[graph theory]], posed by [[Alexander Sidorenko(mathematician)|Alexander Sidorenko]] in 1986. Roughly speaking, the conjecture states that for any [[bipartite graph]] <math>H</math> and [[graph (discrete mathematics)|graph]] <math>G</math> on <math>n</math> vertices with average degree <math>pn</math>, there are at least <math>p^{|E(H)|} n^{|V(H)|}</math> labeled copies of <math>H</math> in <math>G</math>, up to a small error term. Formally, it provides an intuitive inequality about [[graph homomorphism]] densities in [[graphon|graphons]]. The conjectured inequality can be interpreted as a statement that the density of copies of <math>H</math> in a graph is asymptotically minimized by a random graph, as one would expect a <math>p^{|E(H)|}</math> fraction of possible subgraphs to be a copy of <math>H</math> if each edge exists with probability <math>p</math>.
==Statement==
Let <math>H</math> be a graph. Then <math>H</math> is said to have '''Sidorenko's property''' if, for all [[Graphon | graphons]] <math>W</math>, the inequality : <math>t(H,W)\geq t(K_2,W)^{|E(H)|}</math> is true, where <math>t(H,W)</math> is the [[homomorphism density]] of <math>H</math> in <math>W</math>.
Sidorenko's conjecture (1986) states that every bipartite graph has Sidorenko's property.<ref>{{citation | last = Sidorenko | first = Alexander | doi = 10.1007/BF02988307 | issue = 2-4 | journal = Graphs and Combinatorics | pages = 201–204 | title = A correlation inequality for bipartite graphs | volume = 9 | year = 1993}}</ref>
If <math>W</math> is a graph <math>G</math>, this means that the probability of a uniform random mapping from <math>V(H)</math> to <math>V(G)</math> being a homomorphism is at least the product over each edge in <math>H</math> of the probability of that edge being mapped to an edge in <math>G</math>. This roughly means that a randomly chosen graph with fixed number of vertices and average degree has the minimum number of labeled copies of <math>H</math>. This is not a surprising conjecture because the right hand side of the inequality is the probability of the mapping being a homomorphism if each edge map is independent. So one should expect the two sides to be at least of the same order. The natural extension to graphons would follow from the fact that every graphon is the [[limit point]] of some sequence of graphs.
The requirement that <math>H</math> is bipartite to have Sidorenko's property is necessary — if <math>W</math> is a bipartite graph, then <math>t(K_3,W)=0</math> since <math>W</math> is triangle-free. But <math>t(K_2,W)</math> is twice the number of edges in <math>W</math>, so Sidorenko's property does not hold for <math>K_3</math>. A similar argument shows that no graph with an odd cycle has Sidorenko's property. Since a graph is bipartite if and only if it has no odd cycles, this implies that the only possible graphs that can have Sidorenko's property are bipartite graphs.
===Equivalent formulation===
Sidorenko's property is equivalent to the following reformulation: : For all graphs <math>G</math>, if <math>G</math> has <math>n</math> vertices and an average degree of <math>pn</math>, then <math>t(H,G)\geq p^{|E(H)|}</math>.
This is equivalent because the number of homomorphisms from <math>K_2</math> to <math>G</math> is twice the number of edges in <math>G</math>, and the inequality only needs to be checked when <math>W</math> is a graph as previously mentioned.
In this formulation, since the number of non-injective homomorphisms from <math>H</math> to <math>G</math> is at most a constant times <math>n^{|V(H)|-1}</math>, Sidorenko's property would imply that there are at least <math>(p^{|E(H)|}-o(1))n^{|V(H)|}</math> labeled copies of <math>H</math> in <math>G</math>.
==Examples==
As previously noted, to prove Sidorenko's property it suffices to demonstrate the inequality for all graphs <math>G</math>. Throughout this section, <math>G</math> is a graph on <math>n</math> vertices with average degree <math>pn</math>. The quantity <math>\operatorname{hom}(H,G)</math> refers to the number of homomorphisms from <math>H</math> to <math>G</math>. This quantity is the same as <math>n^{|V(H)|}t(H,G)</math>.
Elementary proofs of Sidorenko's property for some graphs follow from the [[Cauchy–Schwarz inequality]] or [[Hölder's inequality]]. Others can be done by using [[spectral graph theory]], especially noting the observation that the number of closed paths of length <math>\ell</math> from vertex <math>i</math> to vertex <math>j</math> in <math>G</math> is the component in the <math>i</math>th row and <math>j</math>th column of the matrix <math>A^\ell</math>, where <math>A</math> is the [[adjacency matrix]] of <math>G</math>.
===Cauchy–Schwarz: The 4-cycle ''C''<sub>4</sub>===
By fixing two vertices <math>u</math> and <math>v</math> of <math>G</math>, each copy of <math>C_4</math> that have <math>u</math> and <math>v</math> on opposite ends can be identified by choosing two (not necessarily distinct) common neighbors of <math>u</math> and <math>v</math>. Letting <math>\operatorname{codeg}(u,v)</math> denote the ''codegree'' of <math>u</math> and <math>v</math> (i.e. the number of common neighbors), this implies : <math>\operatorname{hom}(C_4,G)=\sum_{u,v\in V(G)}\operatorname{codeg}(u,v)^2\geq\frac{1}{n^2}\left(\sum_{u,v\in V(G)}\operatorname{codeg}(u,v)\right)^2</math> by the Cauchy–Schwarz inequality. The sum has now become a count of all pairs of vertices and their common neighbors, which is the same as the count of all vertices and pairs of their neighbors. So : <math>\operatorname{hom}(C_4,G)\geq\frac{1}{n^2}\left(\sum_{x\in V(G)}\deg(x)^2\right)^2\geq\frac{1}{n^2}\left(\frac{1}{n}\left(\sum_{x\in V(G)} \deg(x) \right)^2\right)^2=\frac{1}{n^2}\left(\frac{1}{n}(n\cdot pn)^2\right)^2=p^4n^4</math> by Cauchy–Schwarz again. So : <math>t(C_4,G)=\frac{\operatorname{hom}(C_4,G)}{n^4}\geq p^4</math> as desired.
===Spectral graph theory: The 2''k''-cycle ''C''<sub>2''k''</sub>===
Although the Cauchy–Schwarz approach for <math>C_4</math> is elegant and elementary, it does not immediately generalize to all even cycles. However, one can apply spectral graph theory to prove that all even cycles have Sidorenko's property. Note that odd cycles are not accounted for in Sidorenko's conjecture because they are not bipartite.
Using the observation about closed paths, it follows that <math>\operatorname{hom}(C_{2k},G)</math> is the sum of the diagonal entries in <math>A^{2k}</math>. This is equal to the [[trace (linear algebra)|trace]] of <math>A^{2k}</math>, which in turn is equal to the sum of the <math>2k</math>th powers of the [[eigenvalues and eigenvectors|eigenvalues]] of <math>A</math>. If <math>\lambda_1\geq\lambda_2\geq\dots\geq\lambda_n</math> are the eigenvalues of <math>A</math>, then the [[min-max theorem]] implies that : <math>\lambda_1\geq\frac{\mathbf{1}^\intercal A\mathbf{1}}{\mathbf{1}^\intercal\mathbf{1}}=\frac{1}{n} \sum_{x\in V(G)}\deg(x)=pn,</math> where <math>\mathbf{1}</math> is the vector with <math>n</math> components, all of which are <math>1</math>. But then : <math>\operatorname{hom}(C_{2k},G)=\sum_{i=1}^n\lambda_i^{2k}\geq\lambda_1^{2k}\geq p^{2k}n^{2k}</math> because the eigenvalues of a [[symmetric matrix|real symmetric matrix]] are real. So : <math>t(C_{2k},G)=\frac{\operatorname{hom}(C_{2k},G)}{n^{2k}}\geq p^{2k}</math> as desired.
===Entropy: Paths of length 3===
J.L. Xiang Li and [[Balázs Szegedy]] (2011) introduced the idea of using [[entropy (information theory)|entropy]] to prove some cases of Sidorenko's conjecture. Szegedy (2015) later applied the ideas further to prove that an even wider class of bipartite graphs have Sidorenko's property.<ref>{{citation | last = Szegedy | first = Balázs | authorlink = Balázs Szegedy | arxiv = 1406.6738 | title = An information theoretic approach to Sidorenko's conjecture | year = 2015}}</ref> While Szegedy's proof wound up being abstract and technical, [[Timothy Gowers|Tim Gowers]] and Jason Long reduced the argument to a simpler one for specific cases such as paths of length <math>3</math>.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Gowers |first1=Tim |title=Entropy and Sidorenko’s conjecture — after Szegedy |url=https://gowers.wordpress.com/2015/11/18/entropy-and-sidorenkos-conjecture-after-szegedy/ |website=Gowers's Weblog |accessdate=1 December 2019}}</ref> In essence, the proof chooses a nice [[probability distribution]] of choosing the vertices in the path and applies [[Jensen's inequality]] (i.e. convexity) to deduce the inequality.
==Partial results==
Here is a list of some bipartite graphs <math>H</math> which have been shown to have Sidorenko's property. Let <math>H</math> have bipartition <math>A\sqcup B</math>.
* [[Path (graph theory)|Paths]] have Sidorenko's property, as shown by Mulholland and Smith in 1959 (before Sidorenko formulated the conjecture).<ref>{{citation | last1 = Mulholland | first1 = H.P. | last2 = Smith | first2 = Cedric | author2-link = Cedric Smith (statistician) | doi = 10.1080/00029890.1959.11989387 | issue = 66 | journal = American Mathematical Monthly | pages = 673-683 | title = An inequality arising in genetical theory | year = 1959}}</ref> * [[Tree (graph theory)|Trees]] have Sidorenko's property, generalizing paths. This was shown by Sidorenko in a 1991 paper.<ref>{{citation | last = Sidorenko | first = Alexander | doi = 10.1515/dma.1992.2.5.489 | issue = 3 | journal = Diskretnaya Matematika | pages = 50–65 | title = Inequalities for functionals generated by bipartite graphs | year = 1991}}</ref> * [[Cycle (graph theory)|Cycles of even length]] have Sidorenko's property as previously shown. Sidorenko also demonstrated this in his 1991 paper. * [[Complete bipartite graph]]s have Sidorenko's property. This was also shown in Sidorenko's 1991 paper. * Bipartite graphs with <math>\min\{|A|,|B|\}\leq4</math> have Sidorenko's property. This was also shown in Sidorenko's 1991 paper. * [[Hypercube graph]]s (generalizations of <math>Q_3</math>) have Sidorenko's property, as shown by Hatami in 2008.<ref>{{citation | last = Hatami | first = Hamed | arxiv = 0806.0047 | issue = 175 | journal = Israel Journal of Mathematics | pages = 125–150 | title = Graph norms and Sidorenko's conjecture | year = 2010}}</ref> ** More generally, norming graphs (as introduced by Hatami) have Sidorenko's property. * If there is a vertex in <math>A</math> that is neighbors with every vertex in <math>B</math> (or vice versa), then <math>H</math> has Sidorenko's property as shown by Conlon, Fox, and Sudakov in 2010.<ref>{{citation | last1 = Conlon | first1 = David | author1-link = David Conlon | last2 = Fox | first2 = Jacob | author2-link = Jacob Fox | last3 = Sudakov | first3 = Benny | author3-link = Benny Sudakov | arxiv = 1004.4236 | issue = 20 | journal = Geometric and Functional Analysis | pages = 1354-1366 | title = An approximate version of Sidorenko’s conjecture | year = 2010}}</ref> This proof used the [[dependent random choice]] method. * For all bipartite graphs <math>H</math>, there is some positive integer <math>p</math> such that the ''<math>p</math>-blow-up'' of <math>B</math> has Sidorenko's property. Here, the <math>p</math>-blow-up of <math>H</math> is formed by replacing each vertex in <math>B</math> with <math>p</math> copies of itself, each connected with its original neighbors in <math>A</math>. This was shown by Conlon and Lee in 2018.<ref>{{citation | last1 = Conlon | first1 = David | author1-link = David Conlon | last2 = Lee | first2 = Joonkyung | arxiv = 1809.01259 | title = Sidorenko's conjecture for blow-ups | year = 2018}}</ref> * Some recursive approaches have been attempted, which take a collection of graphs that have Sidorenko's property to create a new graph that has Sidorenko's property. The main progress in this manner was done by Sidorenko in his 1991 paper, Li and Szegedy in 2011<ref>{{citation | last1 = Li | first1 = J.L. Xiang | last2 = Szegedy | first2 = Balázs | author2-link = Balázs Szegedy | arxiv = 1107.1153 | title = On the logarithimic calculus and Sidorenko's conjecture | year = 2011}}</ref>, and Kim, Lee, and Lee in 2013<ref>{{citation | last1 = Kim | first1 = Jeong Han | author1-link = Jeong Han Kim | last2 = Lee | first2 = Choongbum | | last3 = Lee | first3 = Joonkyung | arxiv = 1310.4383 | title = Two Approaches to Sidorenko's Conjecture | year = 2013}}</ref>. ** Li and Szegedy's paper also used entropy methods to prove the property for a class of graphs called "reflection trees." ** Kim, Lee, and Lee's paper extended this idea to a class of graphs with a tree-like substructure called "tree-arrangeable graphs."
However, there are graphs for which Sidorenko's conjecture is still open. An example is the "Möbius strip" graph <math>K_{5,5}\setminus C_{10}</math>, formed by removing a <math>10</math>-cycle from the complete bipartite graph with parts of size <math>5</math>.
[[László Lovász]] proved a local version of Sidorenko's conjecture, i.e. for graphs that are "close" to random graphs in a sense of cut norm.<ref>{{citation | last1 = Lovász | first1 = László | authorlink = László Lovász | arxiv = 1004.3026 | title = Subgraph densities in signed graphons and the local Sidorenko conjecture | year = 2010}}</ref>
==Forcing conjecture==
A sequence of graphs <math>\{G_n\}_{n=1}^{\infty}</math> is called ''quasi-random with density <math>p</math>'' for some density <math>0<p<1</math> if for every graph <math>H</math>, : <math>t(H,G_n)=(1+o(1))p^{|E(H)|}.</math> The sequence of graphs would thus have properties of the [[Erdős–Rényi model|Erdős–Rényi random graph]] <math>G(n,p)</math>.
If the edge density <math>t(K_2,G_n)</math> is fixed at <math>(1+o(1))p</math>, then the condition implies that the sequence of graphs is near the equality case in Sidorenko's property for every graph <math>H</math>.
From Chung, Graham, and Wilson's 1989 paper about quasi-random graphs, it suffices for the <math>C_4</math> count to match what would be expected of a random graph (i.e. the condition holds for <math>H=C_4</math>).<ref>{{citation | last1 = Chung | first1 = Fan | author1-link = Fan Chung | last2 = Graham | first2 = Ronald | author2-link = Ronald Graham | last3 = Wilson | first3 = Richard | author3-link = R. M. Wilson | doi = 10.1007/BF02125347 | issue = 4 | journal = Combinatorica | pages = 345–362 | title = Quasi-random graphs | volume = 9 | year = 1989}}</ref> The paper also asks which graphs <math>H</math> have this property besides <math>C_4</math>. Such graphs are called ''forcing graphs'' as their count controls the quasi-randomness of a sequence of graphs.
The forcing conjecture states the following: : A graph <math>H</math> is forcing if and only if it is bipartite and not a tree. It is straightforward to see that if <math>H</math> is forcing, then it is bipartite and not a tree. Some examples of forcing graphs are even cycles (shown by Chung, Graham, and Wilson). Skokan and Thoma showed that all complete bipartite graphs that are not trees are forcing.<ref>{{citation | last1 = Skokan | first1 = Jozef | last2 = Thoma | first2 = Lubos | doi = 10.1007/s00373-004-0556-1 | issue = 2 | journal = Graphs and Combinatorics | pages = 255–262 | title = Bipartite Subgraphs and Quasi-Randomness | volume = 20 | year = 2004}}</ref>
Sidorenko's conjecture follows from the forcing conjecture. Furthermore, the forcing conjecture would show that graphs that are close to equality in Sidorenko's property must satisfy quasi-randomness conditions.<ref>{{citation | last1 = Conlon | first1 = David | author1-link = David Conlon | last2 = Fox | first2 = Jacob | author2-link = Jacob Fox | last3 = Sudakov | first3 = Benny | author3-link = Benny Sudakov | arxiv = 1004.4236 | issue = 20 | journal = Geometric and Functional Analysis | pages = 1354–1366 | title = An approximate version of Sidorenko’s conjecture | year = 2010}}</ref>

{{short description|Mathematical concept}} In mathematics, specifically in [[control theory]], '''subspace identification (SID)''' aims at identifying [[linear time-invariant theory|linear time invariant]] (LTI) state space models from input-output data. SID does not require that the user parametrizes the system matrices before solving a parametric optimization problem and, as a consequence, SID methods do not suffer from problems related to local minima that often lead to unsatisfactory identification results.
== History ==
SID methods are rooted in the work by the German mathematician [[Leopold Kronecker]] (1823–1891). Kronecker<ref>L. Kronecker, "Algebraische reduktion der schaaren bilinearer formen", S. B. Akad. Berlin, pp. 663–776, 1890.</ref> showed that a power series can be written as a rational function when the rank of the Hankel operator that has the power series as its symbol is finite. The rank determines the order of the polynomials of the rational function.
In the 1960's the work of Kronecker inspired a number of researchers in the area of Systems and Control, like Ho and Kalman, Silverman and Youla and Tissi, to store the [[Markov parameter]]s of an LTI system into a finite dimensional [[Hankel matrix]] and derive from this matrix an (A,B,C) realization of the LTI system. The key observation was that when the Hankel matrix is properly dimensioned versus the order of the LTI system, the rank of the Hankel matrix is the order of the LTI system and the SVD of the Hankel matrix provides a basis of the column space observability matrix and row space of the controllability matrix of the LTI system. Knowledge of this key spaces allows to estimate the system matrices via linear least squares<ref>M. Verhaegen, "Subspace Techniques in System Identification", in Encyclopedia of Systems and Control, https://link.springer.com/referenceworkentry/10.1007/978-1-4471-5102-9_107-1</ref>.
An extension to the stochastic realization problem where we have knowledge only of the Auto-correlation (covariance) function of the output of an LTI system driven by white noise, was derived by researchers like Akaike<ref>H. Akaike, "A new look at the statistical model identification", IEEE Transactions on Automatic Control, vol. 19, pp. 716–723, 1974.</ref>.
A second generation of SID methods attempted to make SID methods directly operate on input-output measurements of the LTI system in the decade 1985–1995. One such generalization was presented under the name of the [[Eigensystem realization algorithm|Eigensystem Realization Algorithm]] (ERA) made use of specific input-output measurements considering the impulse inputs<ref>J.-N. Juang and R. S. Pappa, R. S., "An Eigensystem Realization Algorithm for modal parameter identification and model reduction", Journal of Guidance, Control, and Dynamics. vol. 8, 1985.</ref>. It has been used for modal analysis of flexible structures, like bridges, space structures, etc. These methods have demonstrated to work in practice for resonant structures they did not work well for other type of systems and an input different from an impulse. A new impulse to the development of SID methods was made for operating directly on generic input-output data and avoiding to first explicitly compute the Markov parameters or estimating the samples of covariance functions prior to realizing the system matrices. Pioneers that contributed to these breakthroughs were Van Overschee and De Moor – introducing the N4SID approach<ref>P. Van Overschee and B. De Moor, "N4SID: Subspace algorithms for the identification of combined deterministic-stochastic systems", Automatica, vol. 30 pp. 75–93, 1994.</ref>, Verhaegen – introducing the MOESP approach<ref>M. Verhaegen, "Identification of the deterministic part of MIMO state space models given in innovations form from input-output data", Automatica, vol. 30, pp. 61–74, 1994.</ref> and Larimore – presenting ST in the framework of Canonical Variate Analysis (CVA)<ref>W. Larimore, "Canonical variate analysis in identification, filtering, and adaptive control", in Proceedings of the 29th IEEE Conference on Decision and Control, 1990.</ref>

{{Orphan|date=March 2020}}
The '''MgNet'''<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=He|first=Juncai|last2=Xu|first2=Jinchao|date=July 2019|title=MgNet: A unified framework of multigrid and convolutional neural network|journal=Science China Mathematics|language=en|volume=62|issue=7|pages=1331–1354|doi=10.1007/s11425-019-9547-2|issn=1674-7283|arxiv=1901.10415|bibcode=2019arXiv190110415H}}</ref> is an abstract and unified mathematical framework which simultaneously recovers some [[residual neural network]] (ResNet)<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Sun|first=Jian|last2=Ren|first2=Shaoqing|last3=Zhang|first3=Xiangyu|last4=He|first4=Kaiming|date=2015-12-10|title=Deep Residual Learning for Image Recognition|arxiv=1512.03385v1|bibcode=2015arXiv151203385H|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Sun|first=Jian|last2=Ren|first2=Shaoqing|last3=Zhang|first3=Xiangyu|last4=He|first4=Kaiming|date=2016-03-16|title=Identity Mappings in Deep Residual Networks|arxiv=1603.05027v3|language=en}}</ref> type [[convolutional neural network]]s (CNNs) and multigrid methods<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Xu|first=Jinchao.|date=1992-12-01|title=Iterative Methods by Space Decomposition and Subspace Correction|journal=SIAM Review|volume=34|issue=4|pages=581–613|doi=10.1137/1034116|issn=0036-1445}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Zikatanov|first=Ludmil|last2=Xu|first2=Jinchao|date=May 2017|title=Algebraic multigrid methods *|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/acta-numerica/article/algebraic-multigrid-methods/8FFBCDA39DB9631667396C9CD1F223BF|journal=Acta Numerica|language=en|volume=26|pages=591–721|doi=10.1017/S0962492917000083|issn=0962-4929|arxiv=1611.01917}}</ref> for solving discretized [[partial differential equation]]s (PDEs). As a CNN model, MgNet can be obtained by making some very minor modifications of a classic geometric multigrid method. Actually, connections between ResNet and classical multigrid methods were acknowledged in the original paper of ResNet<ref name=":3" /> from the viewpoint how residuals are applied in both methods. MgNet<ref name=":1" /> makes such a connection more direct and clear, and it makes it possible to directly obtain a class of efficient CNN models by simply making some very minor modification of a typical multigrid cycle but keeping the identically same algorithm structure.
== Main structure and connections with ResNet == One core concept in MgNet, motivated by our research in algebraic multigrid methods,<ref name=":0" /> is the distinction between the so-called data and feature spaces (that are dual to each other). Based on this new concept, MgNet and a further research ({{cite arXiv|eprint=1911.10428v1|authors=Juncai He; Yuyan Chen; Jinchao Xu|title=Constrained Linear Data-feature Mapping for Image Classification|date=2019|class=eess.IV}}) proposes the constrained data-feature mapping model in every grid as
<math>A \ast u=f,</math>
where <math>f</math> belongs to the data space and <math>u</math> belongs to the feature space such that
<math>u \ge 0</math>.
The feature extraction process can then be obtained through an iterative procedure for solving the above system in each grids. For example, if the single step residual correction scheme is applied for the above system, it becomes
<math>u^{i} = u^{i-1} + \sigma \circ B^{i} \ast \sigma(f^{} - A\ast u^{i-1}), \quad i = 1:\nu,</math>
with <math>u \approx u^{\nu}</math>.
If the residual of the above iterative <math>r^i = f - A\ast u^i</math>is further considered, it becomes
<math>r^{i} = r^{i-1} - A\ast \sigma \circ B^i\ast\sigma(r^{i-1}), \quad i=1:\nu.</math>
This is almost the exact basic block scheme in Pre-act ResNet,<ref name=":2" /> which has the form
<math>r^{i} = r^{i-1} - A^i \ast \sigma \circ B^i\ast\sigma(r^{i-1}), \quad i=1:\nu.</math>
The next figure shows the pseudocode of MgNet: [[File:MgNet_Framework.png|alt=|500x500px|center]]
One thing important to note is that the special MgNet Algorithm 1 is identical to a multigrid cycle<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":0" /> if the boxed nonlinear operations are removed in the algorithm.
== Summary == By revealing such a direct connection between CNN and multigrid method, this opens up a new door to the design and study of deep learning models from a more mathematical viewpoint and in particular the rich mathematical techniques developed for multigrid method can be applied in the study of [[deep learning]].

In mathematics, the '''Moy-Prasad filtration''' is a family of [[filtration (mathematics)|filtrations]] of [[p-adic number|''p''-adic]] [[reductive group]]s and their [[Lie algebra]]s, named after Allen Moy and [[Gopal Prasad]]. The family is parameterized by the [[building (mathematics)|Bruhat-Tits building]]; that is, each point of the building gives a different filtration. Alternatively, since the initial term in each filtration at a point of the building is the [[parahoric subgroup]] for that point, the Moy-Prasad filtration can be viewed as a filtration of a parahoric subgroup of a reductive group.
The chief application of the Moy-Prasad filtration is to the [[representation theory]] of ''p''-adic groups, where it can be used to define a certain real number called the '''depth''' of a representation. The representations of depth ''r'' can be better understood by studying the ''r''th Moy-Prasad subgroups. This information then leads to a better understanding of the overall structure of the representations, and that understanding in turn has applications to other areas of mathematics, such as [[number theory]] via the [[Langlands program]].
==History== In their foundational work on the theory of buildings, Bruhat and Tits defined subgroups associated to concave functions of the root system.{{sfn | Bruhat | Tits | 1972 | loc=Section 6.4}} These subgroups are a special case of the Moy-Prasad subgroups, defined when the group is [[Reductive group#Definitions|split]]. The main innovations of Moy and Prasad{{sfn | Moy | Prasad | 1994}} were to generalize Bruhat-Tits's construction to [[quasi-split group]]s, in particular [[algebraic torus|tori]], and to use the subgroups to study the representation theory of the ambient group.
==Examples== The following examples use the ''p''-adic rational numbers <math>\mathbb{Q}_p</math> and the ''p''-adic integers <math>\mathbb{Z}_p</math>. A reader unfamiliar with these rings may instead replace <math>\mathbb{Q}_p</math> by the [[Rational number|rational numbers]] <math>\mathbb{Q}</math> and <math>\mathbb{Z}_p</math> by the [[Integer|integers]] <math>\mathbb{Z}</math> without losing the main idea.
=== Multiplicative group === The simplest example of a ''p''-adic reductive group is <math>\mathbb{Q}_p^\times</math>, the [[multiplicative group]] of ''p''-adic [[Unit (ring theory)|units]]. Since <math>\mathbb{Q}_p^\times</math> is [[Abelian group|abelian]], it has a unique parahoric subgroup, <math>\mathbb{Z}_p^\times</math>. The Moy-Prasad subgroups of <math>\mathbb{Z}_p^\times</math> are the [[Higher unit group|higher unit groups]] <math>U^{(r)}</math>, where for simplicity <math>r</math> is a positive integer: <math display="block">(\mathbb{Z}_p^\times)_r=1+(p\,\mathbb{Z}_p)^r = \{u\in\mathbb{Z}_p^\times:u\equiv1\bmod{p^r}\}.</math>The Lie algebra of <math>\mathbb{Q}_p^\times</math> is <math>\mathbb{Q}_p</math>, and its Moy-Prasad subalgebras are the nonzero [[Ideal (ring theory)|ideals]] of <math>\mathbb{Z}_p</math>:<math display="block">(\mathbb{Z}_p)_r=(p\,\mathbb{Z}_p)^r = \{p^ra : a\in\mathbb{Z}_p\}.</math>More generally, if <math>r</math> is a positive real number then we use the [[Floor and ceiling functions|floor function]] to define the <math>r</math>th Moy-Prasad subgroup and subalgebra: <math display="block">(\mathbb{Z}_p^\times)_r := (\mathbb{Z}_p^\times)_{\lfloor r\rfloor},\qquad(\mathbb{Z}_p)_r := (\mathbb{Z}_p)_{\lfloor r\rfloor}</math>This example illustrates the general phenomenon that although the Moy-Prasad filtration is indexed by the nonnegative real numbers, the filtration jumps only on a discrete, periodic subset, in this case, the natural numbers. In particular, it is usually the case that the <math>r</math>th and <math>s</math>th Moy-Prasad subgroups are equal if <math>s</math> is only slightly larger than <math>r</math>.
=== General linear group === Another important example of a ''p''-adic reductive group is the [[general linear group]] <math>\text{GL}_n(\mathbb{Q}_p)</math>; this example generalizes the previous one because <math>\text{GL}_1(\mathbb{Q}_p) = \mathbb{Q}_p^\times</math>. Since <math>\text{GL}_n(\mathbb{Q}_p)</math> is nonabelian (when <math>n\geq2</math>), it has infinitely many parahoric subgroups. One particular parahoric subgroup is <math>\text{GL}_n(\mathbb{Z}_p)</math>. The Moy-Prasad subgroups of <math>\text{GL}_n(\mathbb{Z}_p)</math> are the subgroups of elements equal to the [[identity matrix]] <math>1</math> modulo high powers of <math>p</math>. Specifically, when <math>r</math> is a positive integer we define<math display="block">\text{GL}_n(\mathbb{Z}_p)_r=1+(p\,\text{M}_n(\mathbb{Z}_p))^r = \{u\in\text{M}_n(\mathbb{Z}_p):u\equiv1\bmod{p^r}\}.</math>where <math>\text{M}_n(\mathbb{Z}_p)</math> is the [[matrix algebra|algebra of ''n × n'' matrices]] with coefficients in <math>\mathbb{Z}_p</math>. The Lie algebra of <math>\text{GL}_n(\mathbb{Q}_p)</math> is <math>\text{M}_n(\mathbb{Q}_p)</math>, and its Moy-Prasad subalgebras are the spaces of matrices equal to the [[zero matrix]] modulo high powers of <math>p</math>; when <math>r</math> is a positive integer we define<math display="block">\text{M}_n(\mathbb{Z}_p)_r=(p\,\text{M}_n(\mathbb{Z}_p))^r = \{u\in\text{M}_n(\mathbb{Z}_p):u\equiv0\bmod{p^r}\}.</math>Finally, as before, if <math>r</math> is a positive real number then we use the [[Floor and ceiling functions|floor function]] to define the <math>r</math>th Moy-Prasad subgroup and subalgebra:<math display="block">\text{GL}_n(\mathbb{Z}_p)_r := \text{GL}_n(\mathbb{Z}_p)_{\lfloor r\rfloor},\qquad\text{M}_n(\mathbb{Z}_p)_r := \text{M}_n(\mathbb{Z}_p)_{\lfloor r\rfloor}</math>In this example, the Moy-Prasad groups would more commonly be denoted by <math>\text{GL}_n(\mathbb{Q}_p)_{x,r}</math> instead of <math>\text{GL}_n(\mathbb{Z}_p)_r</math>, where <math>x</math> is a point of the building of <math>\text{GL}_n(\mathbb{Q}_p)</math> whose corresponding parahoric subgroup is <math>\text{GL}_n(\mathbb{Z}_p).</math>
==Properties== Although the Moy-Prasad filtration is commonly used to study the representation theory of ''p''-adic groups, one can construct Moy-Prasad subgroups over any [[Henselian ring|Henselian]], [[Discrete valuation|discretely valued]] field <math>k</math>, not just over a nonarchimedean local field. In this and subsequent sections, we will therefore assume that the base field <math>k</math> is Henselian and discretely valued, and with ring of integers <math>\mathcal{O}_k</math>. Nonetheless, the reader is welcome to assume for simplicity that <math>k=\mathbb{Q}_p</math>, so that <math>\mathcal{O}_k=\mathbb{Z}_p</math>.
Let <math>G</math> be a reductive <math>k</math>-group, let <math>r\geq0</math>, and let <math>x</math> be a point of the extended Bruhat-Tits building of <math>G</math>. The <math>r</math>th Moy-Prasad subgroup of <math>G(k)</math> at <math>x</math> is denoted by <math>G(k)_{x,r}</math>. Similarly, the <math>r</math>th Moy-Prasad Lie subalgebra of <math>\mathfrak{g}</math> at <math>x</math> is denoted by <math>\mathfrak{g}_{x,r} </math>; it is a [[Free module|free]] <math>\mathcal{O}_k</math>-module spanning <math>\mathfrak{g}_{x,r} </math>, or in other words, a [[Lattice (module)|lattice]]. (In fact, the Lie algebra <math>\mathfrak{g}_{x,r} </math> can also be defined when <math>r<0</math>, though the group <math>G(k)_{x,r}</math> cannot.)
Perhaps the most basic property of the Moy-Prasad filtration is that it is decreasing: if <math>r\leq s </math> then <math>\mathfrak{g}_{x,r}\supseteq\mathfrak{g}_{x,s} </math> and <math>G(k)_{x,r}\supseteq G(k)_{x,s}</math>. It is standard to then define the subgroup and subalgebra<math display="block">G(k)_{x,r+}:=\bigcup_{s>r} G(k)_{x,s}, \qquad \mathfrak{g}_{x,r+}:=\bigcup_{s>r} \mathfrak{g}_{x,s}.</math>This convention is just a notational shortcut because for any <math>r </math>, there is an <math>\varepsilon>0 </math> such that <math>\mathfrak{g}_{x,r+}=\mathfrak{g}_{x,r+\varepsilon}</math> and <math>G(k)_{x,r+}=G(k)_{x,r+\varepsilon}</math>.
The Moy-Prasad filtration satisfies the following additional properties.{{sfn | Hakim | Murnaghan | 2010 | loc=Section 2.5}}
*A '''jump''' in the Moy-Prasad filtration is defined as an index (that is, nonnegative real number) <math>r</math> such that <math>G(k)_{x,r+}\neq G(k)_{x,r}</math>. The set of jumps is [[Discrete space|discrete]] and [[Countable set|countably infinite]]. *If <math>r\leq s</math> then <math>G(k)_{x,r}</math> is a [[normal subgroup]] of <math>G(k)_{x,s}</math> and <math>\mathfrak{g}_{x,r}</math> is an [[Ideal (Lie algebra)|ideal]] of <math>\mathfrak{g}_{x,s}</math>. It is a notational convention in the subject to write <math>G(k)_{x,r:s}:=G(k)_{x,r}/G(k)_{x,s}</math> and <math>\mathfrak{g}_{x,r:s}:=\mathfrak{g}_{x,r}/\mathfrak{g}_{x,s}</math> for the associated quotients. * The quotient <math>G(k)_{x,0:0+}</math> is a reductive group over the [[residue field]] of <math>\mathcal{O}_k</math>, namely, the maximal reductive quotient of the special fiber of the <math>\mathcal{O}_k</math>-group underlying the parahoric <math>G(k)_{x,0}</math>. In particular, if <math>k</math> is a nonarchimedean local field (such as <math>\mathbb{Q}_p</math>) then this quotient is a [[group of lie type|finite group of Lie type]]. *<math>[G(k)_{x,r},G(k)_{x,s}]\subseteq G(k)_{x,r+s}</math> and <math>[\mathfrak{g}_{x,r},\mathfrak{g}_{x,s}]\subseteq\mathfrak{g}_{x,r+s}</math>; here the first bracket is the [[commutator]] and the second is the Lie bracket. * For any automorphism <math>\theta</math> of <math>G</math> we have <math>\theta(G(k)_{x,r})=G(k)_{\theta(x),r}</math> and <math>\text{d}\theta(\mathfrak{g}_{x,r}) = \mathfrak{g}_{\theta(x),r}</math>, where <math>\text{d}\theta</math> is the derivative of <math>\theta</math>. * For any [[uniformizer]] <math>\varpi</math> of <math>k</math> we have <math>\varpi\mathfrak{g}_{x,r}=\mathfrak{g}_{x,r+1}</math>.
Under certain technical assumptions on <math>G</math>, an additional important property is satisfied. By the commutator subgroup property, the quotient <math>G(k)_{x,r:s}</math> is abelian if <math>r\leq s\leq 2r</math>. In this case there is a canonical isomorphism <math>\mathfrak{g}_{x,r:s}\cong G(k)_{x,r:s}</math>, called the '''Moy-Prasad isomorphism'''. The technical assumption needed for the Moy-Prasad isomorphism to exist is that <math>G</math> be '''tame''', meaning that <math>G</math> splits over a [[Tame ramification|tamely ramified]] extension of the base field <math>k</math>. If this assumption is violated then <math>\mathfrak{g}_{x,r:s}</math> and <math>G(k)_{x,r:s}</math> are not necessarily isomorphic.{{sfn | Yu | 2015 |p=|loc=section 5}}
==Depth of a representation== The Moy-Prasad can be used to define an important numerical invariant of a [[smooth representation]] <math>(\pi,V)</math> of <math>G(k)</math>, the depth of the representation: this is the smallest number <math>r</math> such that for some point <math>x</math> in the building of <math>G</math>, there is a nonzero vector of <math>V</math> fixed by <math>G(k)_{x,r+}</math>.
In a sequel to the paper defining their filtration, Moy and Prasad proved a structure theorem for depth-zero supercuspidal representations.{{sfn | Moy | Prasad | 1996 | loc=Proposition 6.6}} Let <math>x</math> be a point in a minimal facet of the building of <math>G</math>; that is, the parahoric subgroup <math>G(k)_{x,0}</math> is a maximal parahoric subgroup. The quotient <math>G(k)_{x,0:0+}</math> is a finite group of Lie type. Let <math>\tau</math> be the inflation to <math>G(k)_{x,0}</math> of a representation of this quotient that is cuspidal in the sense of [[Deligne-Lusztig theory]]. The stabilizer <math>G(k)_x</math> of <math>x</math> in <math>G(k)</math> contains the parahoric group <math>G(k)_{x,0}</math> as a finite-index normal subgroup. Let <math>\rho</math> be an irreducible representation of <math>G(k)_x</math> whose restriction to <math>G(k)_{x,0}</math> contains <math>\tau</math> as a subrepresentation. Then the [[compact induction]] of <math>\rho</math> to <math>G(k)</math> is a depth-zero supercuspidal representation. Moreover, every depth-zero supercuspidal representation is isomorphic to one of this form.
The [[local Langlands correspondence]] is expected to preserve depth, where the depth of an L-parameter is defined using the [[upper numbering]] filtration on the Weil group.{{sfn | Chen | Kamgarpour | 2014 | loc=Section 1}}
==Construction== Although we defined <math>x</math> to lie in the extended building of <math>G</math>, it turns out that the Moy-Prasad subgroup <math>G(k)_{x,r}</math> depends only on the image of <math>x</math> in the reduced building, so that nothing is lost by thinking of <math>x</math> as a point in the reduced building.
Our description of the construction follows Yu's article on smooth models.{{sfn|Yu|2015}}
===Tori=== Since algebraic tori are a particular class of reductive groups, the theory of the Moy-Prasad filtration applies to them as well. It turns out, however, that the construction of the Moy-Prasad subgroups for a general reductive group relies on the construction for tori, so we begin by discussing the case where <math>G=T</math> is a torus. Since the reduced building of a torus is a point there is only one choice for <math>x</math>, and so we will suppress <math>x</math> from the notation and write <math>T(k)_r:=T(k)_{x,r}</math>.
First, consider the special case where <math>T</math> is the [[Weil restriction]] of <math>\mathbb{G}_\text{m}</math> along a finite separable extension <math>\ell</math> of <math>k</math>, so that <math>T(k)=\ell^\times</math>. In this case, we define <math>T(k)_r</math> as the set of <math>a\in\ell^\times</math> such that <math>\text{val}_k(x-1)\geq r</math>, where <math>\text{val}_k:\ell\to\mathbb{R}</math> is the unique [[Valuation (algebra)#Extension of valuations|extension]] of the valuation of <math>k</math> to <math>\ell</math>.
A torus is said to be '''induced''' if it is the direct product of finitely many tori of the form considered in the previous paragraph. The <math>r</math>th Moy-Prasad subgroup of an induced torus is defined as the product of the <math>r</math>th Moy-Prasad subgroup of these factors.
Second, consider the case where <math>r=0</math> but <math>T</math> is an arbitrary torus. Here the Moy-Prasad subgroup <math>T(k)_0</math> is defined as the integral points of the [[Néron model|Néron lft-model]] of <math>T</math>.{{sfn|Bosch|Lütkebohmert|Raynaud|1990|loc=Chapter 10}} This definition agrees with the previously given one when <math>T</math> is an induced torus.
It turns out that every torus can be embedded in an induced torus. To define the Moy-Prasad subgroups of a general torus <math>T</math>, then, we choose an embedding of <math>T</math> in an induced torus <math>S</math> and define <math>T(k)_r:=T(k)_0\cap S(k)_r</math>. This construction is independent of the choice of induced torus and embedding.
===Reductive groups=== For simplicity, we will first outline the construction of the Moy-Prasad subgroup <math>G(k)_{x,r}</math> in the case where <math>G</math> is [[Reductive group#Definitions|split]]. After, we will comment on the general definition.
Let <math>T</math> be a maximal split torus of <math>G</math> whose apartment contains <math>x</math>, and let <math>\Phi</math> be the [[root system]] of <math>G</math> with respect to <math>T</math>.
For each <math>\alpha\in\Phi</math>, let <math>U_\alpha</math> be the root subgroup of <math>G</math> with respect to <math>\alpha</math>. As an abstract group <math>U_\alpha</math> is isomorphic to <math>\mathbb{G}_\text{a}</math>, though there is no canonical isomorphism. The point <math>x</math> determines, for each root <math>\alpha</math>, an additive valuation <math>v_{\alpha,x}:U_\alpha(k)\to\mathbb{R}</math>. We define <math>U_\alpha(k)_{x,r}:=\{u\in U_\alpha(k) : v_{\alpha,x}(u)\geq r\}</math>.
Finally, the Moy-Prasad subgroup <math>G(k)_{x,r}</math> is defined as the subgroup of <math>G(k)</math> generated by the subgroups <math>U_\alpha(k)_{x,r}</math> for <math>\alpha\in\Phi</math> and the subgroup <math>T(k)_r</math>.
If <math>G</math> is not split, then the Moy-Prasad subgroup <math>G(k)_{x,r}</math> is defined by unramified descent from the quasi-split case, a standard trick in Bruhat-Tits theory. More specifically, one first generalizes the definition of the Moy-Prasad subgroups given above, which applies when <math>G</math> is split, to the case where <math>G</math> is only quasi-split, using the [[relative root system]]. From here, the Moy-Prasad subgroup can be defined for an arbitrary <math>G</math> by passing to the maximal unramified extension <math>k^\text{nr}</math> of <math>k</math>, a field over which every reductive group, and in particular <math>G</math>, is quasi-split, and then taking the fixed points of this Moy-Prasad group under the Galois group of <math>k^\text{nr}</math> over <math>k</math>.
===Group schemes=== The <math>k</math>-group <math>G</math> carries much more structure than the group <math>G(k)</math> of rational points: the former is an [[algebraic variety]] whereas the second is only an abstract group. For this reason, there are many technical advantages to working not only with the abstract group <math>G(k)</math>, but also the variety <math>G(k)</math>. Similarly, although we described <math>G(k)_{x,r}</math> as an abstract group, a certain subgroup of <math>G(k)</math>, it is desirable for <math>G(k)_{x,r}</math> to be the group of integral points of a [[group scheme]] <math>G_{x,r}</math> defined over the ring of integers, so that <math>G(k)_{x,r}=G_{x,r}(\mathcal{O}_k)</math>. In fact, it is possible to construct such a group scheme <math>G_{x,r}</math>.
===Lie algebras=== Let <math>\mathfrak{g}</math> be the Lie algebra of <math>G</math>. In a similar procedure as for reductive groups, namely, by defining Moy-Prasad filtrations on the Lie algebra of a torus and the Lie algebra of a root group, one can define the Moy-Prasad Lie algebras <math>\mathfrak{g}_{x,r}</math> of <math>\mathfrak{g}</math>; they are free <math>\mathcal{O}_k</math>-modules, that is, <math>\mathcal{O}_k</math>-lattices in the <math>k</math>-vector space <math>\mathfrak{g}</math>. When <math>r\geq0</math>, it turns out that <math>\mathfrak{g}_{x,r}</math> is just the Lie algebra of the <math>\mathcal{O}_k</math>-group scheme <math>G_{x,r}</math>.
===Indexing set=== We have defined the Moy-Prasad filtration at the point <math>x</math> to be indexed by the set <math>\mathbb{R}</math> of real numbers. It is common in the subject to extend the indexing set slightly, to the set <math>\widetilde{\mathbb{R}}</math> consisting of <math>\mathbb{R}</math> and formal symbols <math>r+</math> with <math>r\in\mathbb{R}</math>. The element <math>r+</math> is though of as being infinitesimally larger than <math>r</math>, and the filtration is extended to this case by defining <math>G(k)_{x,r+}:=\bigcup_{s>r}G(k)_{x,s}</math>. Since the valuation on <math>k</math> is discrete, there is <math>\varepsilon>0</math> such that <math>G(k)_{x,r+}=G(k)_{x,r+\varepsilon}</math>.

{{use dmy dates|date=May 2020}} [[File:Lahur_Sessa_by_Thiago_Cruz.jpg|thumb|Sissa ibn Dahir (artists impression)]] The [[brahmin]] '''Sissa''' ibn Dahir (also called Sessa or Sassa) is a [[mythical]] character from [[India]], known for the invention of [[Chaturanga]], the Indian predecessor of [[chess]], and the [[Wheat and chessboard problem|Wheat and Chessboard Problem]] he would have presented to the king when he was asked what reward he'd like for that invention.''[https://books.google.com.tr/books?id=-8dLAAAAcAAJ&dq=Biographical%20dictionary%20of%20Ibn%20Khallikan%2C%20vol.%20III&pg=PP9#v=onepage&q=Sissa&f=false Ibn Khallikan's Biographical Dictionary Vol.3 (1814)]'' , p.71 ff == A legend of the invention of chess == === Synopsis === Sissa invents chess for an Indian king for educational purposes. In gratitude, the King asks Sissa how he wants to be rewarded. Sissa wishes to receive an amount of grain which is the sum of one grain on the first square of the chess board, and which is then doubled on every following square.[https://books.google.com.tr/books?id=L79FAQAAMAAJ&lpg=PA400&ots=5M3JQ0BXOg&dq=sissa%20chess%20married%20with%20daughter&pg=PA400#v=onepage&q=sissa%20&f=false ''The Universal Magazine of Knowledge and Pleasure'' (1797),], "Origin of the Game of Chess", pp400-1 This request is now known as the [[Wheat and chessboard problem|Wheat and Chessboard Problem]], and forms the basis of various mathematical and philosophical questions. === Historical origin === Until the nineteenth century, the legend of Sissa was one of several theories about the [[History of chess|origin of chess]]. Today it is mainly regarded as a myth because there is no clear picture of the origin of [[chaturanga]] (an ancient Indian chess game), and from which modern chess has developed. The context of the mythical Sissa is described in detail in ''A History of Chess''. There are many variations and inconsistencies, and therefore little can be confirmed historically. Nevertheless, the legend of Sissa is placed by most sources in a Hindu kingdom between 400 and 600 AD, in an era after the invasion of [[Alexander the Great]]. The myth is often told from a Persian and Islamic perspective.[[A History of Chess|Murray, H.J.R. (1913), ''A history of chess'', Oxford.]]
However, the oldest known narrative believed to have been the basis for the legend of Sissa is from before the [[Islam]]. It tells of Husiya, daughter of Balhait, a queen whose son is killed by a rebel, but of whom she does not initially hear the news. This news is subtly announced to her through the chess game that Sissa introduced to her.Gordon ''et al'' (ed., 2018) ''[[iarchive:TarikhAlYaqubi/page/n3/mode/2up|The Works of Ibn Wadih Al-Yaqubi]]'', Brill, pp.354-357 == Sources == This article has been created by partial adoption from and translation of the Dutch Wikipedia [[:nl:Sissa_(mythische_brahmaan)|Sissa (Mythische Brahmaan)]].
